characters: MASK COMING OVER JANE'S FACE 127 CLOSE SHOT
AS MRS. MASON REMOVES HER HAT
AT DOOR OF DOOLITTLE'S PRIVATE OFFICE
THE PARACHUTE TANGLED UP IN THE
CLERKS AND STENOGRAPHERS LOOKING AFTER THEM -
SHEETS OF PAPER DRIFTING DOWN THE SCREEN

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: Superimposed title comes in which reads: Greater New York has a population of 7,434,346, among the least important of whom is......

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hand runs down telephone book page and stops at: John H. Mason - Atty. 258 Broadway

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING DOWN
dialogues.text: Pedestrian and vehicle traffic crowd the street in front the office building. CAMERA CENTERS on one figure in the crowd, Johnny, who walks slowly along the sidewalk gazing steadily at something he carries in his hands. CAMERA MOV DOWN AND SHOOTS OVER JOHNNY'S SHOULDER at what he is gazi at. It is a large photograph of Jane. CAMERA MOVES BACK T MEDIUM SHOT as Johnny continues on his way, still absorbe in the picture. A vicious bump from a passer-by yanks Joh back from dream realms to the work-a-day world.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (murmuring an apology) Sorry! The passer-by has disappeared into the crowd. Johnny is a to go on, suddenly realizes he is in front of his office building, quickly puts the photograph in his brief case a enters the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts down the Arcade toward the elevators. A middle- aged man greets him in passing.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: "Morning, Mr. Mason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerily) Good morning! A young lady is next to throw him a greeting.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG LADY
dialogues.text: Hello, Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Lovely morning! A third greeting comes from a young man about his own age

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Hi, Johnny!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Beautiful morning! By now he has reached an open elevator which is filling w people. The door of the elevator next to it opens and sta to discharge its passengers. A starter is stationed betwe the two elevators. A definite reaction from the starter a he sees Johnny. Johnny is about to enter the first elevat then, seeing that the second one is empty, starts toward He finds his way barred by the starter who warmly grips h hand.

dialogues.speaker: STARTER
dialogues.text: "Morning, Mr. Mason.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Harry, it's a marvelous morning! The starter has one hand behind his back. He is violently gesturing a signal to the operator of the second elevator

dialogues.speaker: STARTER
dialogues.text: Have a good trip?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Sensational!

dialogues.speaker: STARTER
dialogues.text: Great city, Boston!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Terrific!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets the pantomimed signal of the starter, bangs the d shut, and his elevator starts upward.

dialogues.speaker: FEATURING JOHNNY AND STARTER
dialogues.text: The starter is shoving Johnny back to the first elevator. Johnny manages to hand starter a cigar as he enters the elevator. The elevator is now full, and the operator wait for the signal to start. The starter looks toward the dia of the second elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second elevator is approaching the tenth floor and continuing up.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: The starter gives the signal. The door closes, the elevat starts up.

dialogues.speaker: AT ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: The door opens, and several passengers emerge, including Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the personnel of the law firm -- clerks, stenographer telephone girl -- are lined up watching the door.

dialogues.speaker: THE OFFICE BOY
dialogues.text: He stands against the wall clutching a string which runs upward from his hand. CAMERA PANS to take in the entrance door. We see the knob turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He yanks the string.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE DOOR
dialogues.text: It has opened; and as Johnny enters, a contraption arrang over the door opens; and Johnny is showered with rice an old shoes. There are whoops and shrieks from off scene. O voice starts singing: "Happy Bridegroom, yoo-hoo" to tune вЂњHappy Birthday" and others join in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny looking on bewilderedly while the office personnel sings.

dialogues.speaker: EMPLOYEES
dialogues.text: (singing) Happy Bridegroom, yoo-hoo! Happy Bridegroom, yoo-hoo! Happy Bridegroom, Happy Bridegroom, Happy Bridegroom, yoo-hoo! The song ends with laughter and ad lib chatter as Johnny' office mates surround him, pumping his hand, whacking his back, congratulating or razzing him, according to their m

dialogues.speaker: AD LIB
dialogues.text: A business trip. Huh?... Where's the little woman, Johnny -- why didn't you bring her along?... Is she one of the Lodges or one of the Cabots?... What's she got that I haven't got?... You'd better be careful with your expense account -- no extras now!... That's what you get for going out of town!... You old bluebeard, you!... I'm going to sue you for breach of promise!... Today our Johnny is a man!...

dialogues.speaker: STENOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Johnny, what's she like?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute! I can't describe her -- nobody could. But it just so happens I've got a picture of her. He opens up his brief case and produces the photograph previously established. It is snatched out of his hand by one of the clerks who rushes out of the scene with it. Th others rush after him. A chorus of whistles, screams and  other extravagant reactions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excited and thrilled at the sensation caused by the mere photograph of his bride, but trying not to show it. Carte comes into Shot, carrying a batch of legal papers. He is type who has had but one love affair in all his life -- himself.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: Well, well, well!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Hello, Carter.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: So you combined pleasure with business! Wait till Judge Doolittle hears about this, my boy!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Hears about what?

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: About your getting married on his time -- and without his consent -- (significantly) Or his daughter's.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Well, what's she got to do about it?

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: (smirking) Well, now, my boy -- the favorite topic of conversation around these parts has been that you and Miss Doolittle --

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Aw, Malarkey! Office talk, Carter. Isn't a word of truth in it!

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: Judge Doolittle may not think so.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (fiercely)  Is that so? Well, if he doesn't like it, he can lump it. Before he can finish, the rest of the staff come into the scene, following the clerk holding the photograph.

dialogues.speaker: AD LIB
dialogues.text: (as clerk returns photograph) You never asked me for my picture, Johnny. When's the next train leave for Boston?... Aren't I as pretty as that?... Johnny, has she got a sister?... No wonder we couldn't compete... I want one of them too!... I wish the boss'd send me out of town!... Never knew you had it in you, Johnny!...

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP
dialogues.text: Suddenly there is a melting away of the group around John as the clerks start for their cubicles and the stenos ret to their desks and make a great show of being busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is suddenly alone -- the photograph of his new bride clutched in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Mason! Johnny turns, registers consternation.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Oh, good morning, Judge Doolittle!

dialogues.speaker: AT DOOR
dialogues.text: Judge Doolittle has entered and stands, frowning, in the midst of rice and old shoes. He's a formidable old codger who has terrified many a witness. Doolittle is somewhat d and wears an acousticon arrangement to facilitate his hea He has a habit of speaking in a very low voice, while all his employees have been trained to raise their voices in talking to him. Throughout the entire scene between Dooli and Johnny, Doolittle will speak in a low voice and Johnn will speak loudly, almost shouting at times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's all this mess? CAMERA PANS him up to Johnny. Johnny takes off his hat.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Ah -- Well, it seems everybody around here found out that I -- er -- I -- while I was in Boston --

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: What were you doing in Boston?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Why, you sent me sir. Don't you remember you sent me up there to get a deposition on the Higgins versus Higgins case!

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Did you get it?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Well, what's all this? What's all this horseplay about?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Well, while I was in Boston, after I got the deposition I had a few hours to spare and so I -- just a few hours -- and I --

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Go on! Go on!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (gulps) I got married!

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (sharply) You WHAT?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (shouts)  I got married.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (as if he hadn't heard right) You got married?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. I got married.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Come into my office!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. CAMERA PANS with him as he strides toward his office, fol by Johnny. It somehow resembles a march to the guillotine

dialogues.speaker: AT DOOR OF DOOLITTLE'S PRIVATE OFFICE
dialogues.text: Doolittle enters with Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at door of his office. He stares towards Doolittle's offi with a smirk on his face; dry-washes his hands and exits into his office.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE'S DESK
dialogues.text: On the wall behind the desk are two paintings. One of Jud Doolittle in his magisterial robes and the other of Chief Justice Hughes of the United States, in his robes. Doolit is seated at his desk glaring at Johnny who stands facing him like a prisoner at the bar. Johnny has the brief case one hand and the framed picture of Jane in the other.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Where's the deposition? Johnny lays Jane's photograph on the desk as he opens the brief case and takes the deposition from it, which he han folded, to Doolittle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are, sir. As Doolittle opens up the paper to look at it, a letter f out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside a large, hand-drawn heart, which covers the page o note paper, is written: To the party of the first part: I love you. (signed) Part of the second part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Doolittle picks up the letter.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (very much embarrassed) Oh, that's -- that's just sort of a letter. Doolittle hands it back. Johnny stuffs the letter into hi pocket with increasing embarrassment. Doolittle adjusts h glasses and starts to read the deposition. He addresses J without looking up.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: So you got married?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Doolittle looks up and glances significantly at a framed picture on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a photograph of Doolittle's daughter and upon it is written: "To Father, with love, Eunice."

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I imagine this will be a surprise to  some people.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir! (catches himself as he realizes the significance of Doolittle's glance at the picture of his daughter) No, sir! I mean -- well -- I don't know. It all happened rather suddenly. You see, we met on Boston Common the night I arrived, and I'd had a bite at Thompson's Spa -- and then I took a little stroll around the Common and -- and I saw her standing there -- she was just standing there -- she had a cinder in her eye. Doolittle looks up suddenly from reading the deposition.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: In her eye.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Whose eye?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Jane -- Mrs. Mason -- my wife.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Of course, she wasn't my wife then -- she's my wife now, though. And I got the cinder out of her eye and --

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: And you married her.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Quick work, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Oh Judge, we knew -- we knew the minute we looked at each other -- we knew -- we knew the minute we looked at each other.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You did!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Last year there were nearly a half a million divorces in this country. Congratulations, Mason!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, sir. An office boy comes in with papers he puts on Doolittle's desk.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE BOY
dialogues.text: Mr. Hutch would like your opinion on this, sir. (he starts out, and as he passes Johnny, hands him a letter) Oh, this is for you, Mr. Mason... special messenger. It's marked "Rush - Important." (exits) Johnny takes the letter, glances at the envelope, registe delight. Then, aware of Doolittle's eyes fixed on him, he hastily puts the letter in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (glancing up from papers office boy brought in) Rush? Important? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Oh, it's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (severely) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Oh -- it's a letter from my wife.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Your wife? What did you do -- leave her in Boston?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Oh, no. She's right here, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Here -- in town?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (the great cross- examiner) If your wife's in town, why did she write you a letter?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Well, she likes to write letters, Judge. Yes, it's a sort of little custom we have. She wrote me a letter the first day she met me, right as soon as she got home. She's written to me every day since. Even coming down on the train together she wrote me. You see, when I get a letter from her, it's sort of like a sort of visit, you see.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Hm -- mmm.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Judge -- we -- when two people get married, they usually go on a honeymoon.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I didn't. I don't approve of honeymoons -- waste of time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh -- huh. Well, you know how women are, and Mrs. Mason and I --

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: What about Higgins against Higgins? You're the only one in the office who knows this case and it's on the calendar for next week.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: If I could get a continuance --

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Opposing counsel wouldn't consent.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: But I talked to Mr. Hornblow this morning and he agreed to a continuance.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Well, all right -- take a week.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: A week! Well, Judge, I'm afraid we wouldn't be able to make it ina week.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: We couldn't make it in a week!

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Make what?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: My wife and I had sort of planned a trip to Europe on the Normandie.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Oh, well -- take two weeks then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An envelope is lying on top of a bouquet of dahlias in a large box. A hand comes in, takes the envelope and remove the note inside. CAMERA MOVES UP to CLOSE UP NOTE. It is written on the stationery of the law firm of Doolittle, Messerschmidt, Doolittle and Hutch. The note reads: Dear mother: Had to rush from the train to the office. Will be home fo tea this afternoon. Love, Johnny

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.S. Bringing with me a lovely girl I met in Boston.

dialogues.speaker: TABLE
dialogues.text: CAMERA is on Mrs. Mason, Johnny's mother.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: And after I got the cinder out of Jane's eye we talked for a little while and then we took a little walk around the Common.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Yes? CAMERA MOVES BACK to take in Johnny and Jane. Jane is sip her tea with exaggerated casualness.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: And -- er -- We walked for quite some time. And then we went over to Thompson's Spa for a bite --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (stymied)  And we had a bite.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Well! Rather an unconventional meeting, wasn't it? There seems nothing else to say.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (brightly) These cookies are delicious!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: They're made with sour cream.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (blurts out suddenly I'm crazy about Jane! Mrs. Mason starts so violently she spills some tea.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (to Jane) John's so young and impulsive...

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Oh, now Mother, wait a minute. This is different.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (to Jane) Are you visiting relatives here in New York, my dear?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Well, yes and no. We -- Not exactly.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I came over with Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (horrified) From Boston? Together? Last night?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Why, yes, Mother, we thought that as long as we were engaged --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Engaged!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh, I know how upset you must be, Mrs. Mason. You know so little about me -- and it all happened so suddenly --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Well I should think it was sudden! What did your family have to say about it?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I have no family.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Oh. (there is implied criticism in the syllable) Didn't John say something about your taking a course in journalism?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Yes, but I gave it up after I met Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yes -- I'm sort of a post graduate course.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (her face brightens) Oh -- My dear, if you have a talent for writing -- (she becomes suddenly motherly) Take my advice and develop it while you're young. One needs all one's time and energy for a career.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Don't you think marriage is a career in itself?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Oh, indeed! Emphatically! That's why one mustn't rush into it pell-mell. Marriage is a business -- a very  serious business. A partnership in the strictest sense of the word. One must prepare for it. There are so many things to learn. Jane looks at Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Well, Jane'll learn all of those -- after we're married.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: I hope and pray that that day will not come for many years!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Well, Mother -- What do you mean -- do you mean we shouldn't --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Emphatically not! There's no reason for Jane to develop into a little household drudge. Oh, I hope you understand I have nothing against Jane. In fact, I like her -- I like her very much.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Well, I'm glad you do, Mother, because... You remember a little while ago you asked Jane whether she'd come to New York to visit relatives? Jane waits breathlessly.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Well, as a matter of fact, she has come to New York to visit relatives. She's visiting some right now -- you see -- He can't finish -- looks desperately at Jane.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: We're married. Mrs. Mason stares at them uncomprehensively for an instan Her mouth opens and her hands go convulsively to her che

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Ohhhh --

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (pitifully) Now, Mother -- everybody gets married sooner or later --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (a cry of panic) Johnny, get the smelling salts! She rushes over and starts to chafe Mrs. Mason's wrists. Mrs. Mason is gasping for breath like a fish out of water Johnny hovers over her, agonized and scared.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: What do they look like? Mother, where are the smelling salts? Mrs. Mason gestures weakly in the direction of the bathro Johnny rushes out. Jane vigorously chafes Mrs. Mason's wr

dialogues.speaker: AT DIVAN
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mason is stretched out on the divan. She looks as if she has just been brought home from the hospital. She spe in a weary, martyred voice.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Ohhhh... What's done is done. You'll have children of your own, I suppose. CAMERA DRAWS BACK to take in Johnny and Jane sitting in c which face the divan. They are haggard and dishevelled.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: And you'll love them and devote your life to them, and then they'll grow up and leave you and you'll say to yourself, it's all right, that's the way it is, you've served your purpose.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Oh, Mother, don't excite yourself  any more.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm all right now. She starts to get up. Johnny and Jane help her to her fee She takes Jane's hand.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: I wish you every possible happiness and joy. (her voice trembles) I think perhaps I'd better go to bed. I'm all right. I'm all right. (she starts to exit, then turns with a sudden grey thought) I'll find a place to live, of course.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Some place to live! Well, of course not Mother, you'll stay with us. (Mrs. Mason shakes her head) We're, well, we're going to finda new apartment. (again Mrs. Mason shakes her head) We've talked this over and Jane'll insist. Won't you, darling?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (not too convincingly) Why, we couldn't think of anything else.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (shakes her head desolately) Well, we'll see.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mason totters, turns abruptly and exits to her bed-r Johnny and Jane look after her.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY AND JANE
dialogues.text: Looking off after Mrs. Mason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you see, I told you it would be all right.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (as she goes into his arms) Oh, Johnny, maybe we shouldn't have gotten married. Maybe we shouldn't have gotten married at all.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: Atmosphere of just before sailing. Through the Fade, the sound of a steamer whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A steward passes through the crowd and comes down the gangplank calling:

dialogues.speaker: STEWARD
dialogues.text: All visitors ashore, please! All visitors ashore, please!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: in the midst of a similar group bidding farewell to frien and relatives. All through the scene there is a constant movement of people in the background. Mrs. Mason tightly clutches a paper wrapped bag. A hoarse blast from the ste and Mrs. Mason goes rigid.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (to Jane) Don't let him eat too many strawberries.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I won't.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: He gets rashes. And don't forget to  make him wear his raincoat in London.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I won't.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: He had pneumonia once.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Oh, Mother, that was twelve years ago. I feel fine now.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (to Jane) And take good care of yourself, too. Mrs. Mason and Jane exchange an embarrassed embrace and a kiss on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Mrs. Mason.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (choking) Take good care of him. She looks at Johnny an instant as if to fix his image in mind, then throws her arms around him. Her embrace is muc different than the one she gave Jane. She holds onto her as if she never expected to see him again. Johnny is touc and embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Mother. Aw now, Mother -- it's only two weeks, you know.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (in a strangled voice) I know -- Goodbye. She finally lets him go.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Goodbye. She gives them what she thinks is a smile, but it's reall tense twisting of her lips. She starts to go, then she remembers something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. She hands the box she is carrying to Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: The heating pad. You forgot to pack it. She makes a feeble effort to wave to them and exits. John looks after her, perplexed and wistful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With tears streaming down her cheeks, she moves past peop waving farewell to those on the boat. She turns once as i she means to wave too -- then turns and plods doggedly ah

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny and Jane come into the corridor glancing at doors. Johnny has the heating pad under his arm. They find their stateroom and go up to the door numbered 504.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Here it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny and Jane enter and look around. It's the smallest first class cabin on the boat with a single bed in it. Th only other furniture is a tiny desk and a couple of chair

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY AND JANE
dialogues.text: Jane tries to conceal her disappointment at the cell-like size of the room, but Johnny gets it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Ah, what do you think of it?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (obvious hypocrisy Well, it's -- it's cozy.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: It's the only one they had left. I think we can do better after the boat sails.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh, what for? I love it. It's so intimate. Jane spies a package on the luggage deposited by the desk

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's heavily wrapped in tissue paper. Jane picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Oh that! -- that's nothing -- He grabs it and keeps it out of her reach.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (eagerly) Is it something somebody gave you? Oh, I know it's for me. Let me see it!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (still embarrassed Oh, no -- no, it isn't.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (as though he were holding out on her) It is too. Let me see it!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: But it's just something I forgot to pack.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Well, what are you being so mysterious about? Let me see it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: It's nothing... She takes the package and Johnny looks away, then watches her out of the corner of his eye, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I bet it's a going away present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane's hands tearing off the wrapping.

dialogues.speaker: JANE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Oh, Johnny, you shouldn't have done this. Her hand rips off the last piece of tissue revealing a pi of herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane looks at the picture, looks at Johnny, looks back at the picture, enormously pleased.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh, Johnny, you fool! (throwing her arms around his neck and kissing him)

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (in a weak attempt to laugh it off) Well, gee whizz, I couldn't leave it in the office! He looks away, reacts to something off scene.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Jane --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (her head still on his shoulder) What?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You know, when I was in school I was taught that two things can't occupy the same place at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What? (she draws back, looks questioningly at Johnny, follows his gaze) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- from Jane and Johnny's angle.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO JANE AND JOHNNY
dialogues.text: They cross over to the bed, stare at it.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Well, we'll get the steward to get us a bigger bed.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You couldn't get a bigger bed in here though.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh, I think it's big enough. She stretches out on one side of the bed and looks up at Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Wait till you try to turn around. Is it all right?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Sure it is. Johnny lies on the other side of the bed, puts his arm ar Jane and they sink back on the pillow.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Let's see. That's not so bad. Why there's oceans of room here. A look of blissful content steals over them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are luxuriantly stretched out.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (dreamily) Johnny, this is the first time in my life I've ever been away from America.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (almost purring) Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Isn't it just beautiful?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (the complete sophisticate) Yeh, yeh, I guess so -- (with a far-away look) Jane...

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (meltingly) What, Johnny?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (reminiscently and tenderly) Do you remember that cinder I took out of your eye in Boston?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (positively overflowing with gooey love) I'll never forget it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (self-recriminating) Do you know that I threw it away? I shouldn't have done that. I should have kept that cinder -- put it ina locket or something. If it hadn't been for that cinder, maybe we'd never have met...

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (horrified at the very idea!) Don't say that, Johnny -- we had to meet.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (grudgingly admits) Yeh, yeh, I guess you're right. (but still clinging to his original fearsome idea) But still... if it hadn't been for that cinder --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh, Johnny -- isn't it just beautiful? A hoarse blast from the steamer whistle. She edges a bit closer to him and they turn to look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (with infinite tenderness) Bon voyage, darling.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (same manner) Bon voyage. They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Where is stateroom 504?

dialogues.speaker: STEWARD
dialogues.text: First room to your left, sir. There is a knock on the door. Johnny and Jane exchange a startled glance.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny and Jane get off the bed. The door opens and Carte enters. We get a feeling he has come on a mission which h finds exceedingly pleasant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hello, Carter. Nice of you to come down.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: Judge Doolittle sent me.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: He did? Jane comes into the scene. Johnny introduces her to Carte

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (to Carter) Carter, this is Miss -- Mrs. -- This is my wife. Darling, this is Mr. Carter from the office.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: Happy to know you. (to Johnny) It's a good thing I got here in time. You've got just ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Ten minutes for what?

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: (hugely enjoys the moment) To get off the boat. Jane reacts to this. Johnny turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: To get off the -- What're you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: Higgins against Higgins.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (a note of doom in his voice) What about Higgins against Higgins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Higgins against Higgins goes on the calendar for next week.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Oh, no, no. That's where you're mistaken. I got a continuance for a whole month.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: You think you did.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I did! Why didn't you ask Hornblow about it? He gave me his word of honor.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Well, you know Hornblow.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (frantically) Johnny, they can't do this to you!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: No, they can't do this to me!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What does Doolittle think he is -- a puppet?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: What does he think I am -- a puppet or something?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Some kind of a pawn he can push around any way he likes?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yes -- push all over the place?

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: (to Johnny) Is that what you want me to tell Doolittle?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (shouts) Yes! Flustered, Johnny addresses Carter apologetically.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Oh, Carter, wait a minute! Are you sure that Higgins case is going on next week?

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: Monday morning at nine o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Will you excuse us a minute? -- Jane -- Carter saunters out into the corridor, leaving the door o Johnny steers Jane to other side of room.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I'm glad you said that, Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yeah -- yeah - Jane, look -- This Higgins versus Higgins is a pretty important case.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I don't care if it's the most important case in the world -- it isn't as important as our honeymoon, is it?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Oh, no -- of course not, darling. (Jane starts to wipe his mouth with her handkerchief) But what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You've got lipstick all over your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (continuing) A lawyer is sort of like a doctor or  a soldier -- you -- you've got to disregard your own convenience.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Convenience! You don't call this a convenience! During this scene Carter can be seen pacing back and fort in the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: No, no darling -- now listen, darling, believe me I'd tell Doolittle to jump in the lake -- even at the risk of losing my job, but if I win this case -- I have a chance to get into the firm. And -- And a firm like this -- He stops suddenly as he notes the expression on her face his jaw hardens.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (continues) But it's my honeymoon! And Doolittle knows it's my honeymoon! CAMERA PANS with him as he starts pacing back and forth. the background Carter paces in the corridor, passing the open door. Johnny looks up at the moment that Carter pass giving him a significant look.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (with inflection dimuendo) There are just some things a man just can't do. There are some things aman just can't do!

dialogues.speaker: NORMANDIE LEAVING
dialogues.text: Crowd on dock waving farewells. Among them, Jane and John

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE ANGLE
dialogues.text: Johnny and Jane are both glum -- Jane's eyes are wet -- a they look out toward the Normandie sailing away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Carter thought it was funny! He laughed! Oh, I hate that -- that liver-pill!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: If they ever try pulling anything like this again, I...

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: And I hate that Judge Do-nothing. I -- I wish someone would step on that ear-thing of his.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Well, we still have the tickets here...

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: And I hope Higgins beats Higgins! (she breaks) Oh, Johnny -- He puts his arm around her and they stare bleakly out to sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under it name plate containing a card with name: MR. AND MRS. JOHN H. MASON and under it the half of anoth card, with name:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HARRIET MASON
dialogues.text: A woman's gloved hand comes into Shot and presses button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie, the cook, carrying a mixing spoon and flushed and grumpy from her labors in the kitchen, goes to the door a admits Mrs. Mason. Annie wears a black uniform covered by  large kitchen apron.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (holding forth a paper bag) The alligator pears, Annie. Annie grunts, snatches the paper package. Mrs. Mason has turned to take off her coat. She turns now hand it to Annie but finds she has gone.

dialogues.speaker: JANE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (calling from bedroom) Johnny!

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (as she passes bedroom) It's your mother-in-law.

dialogues.speaker: JANE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Oh, hello, dear!

dialogues.speaker: JANE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Oh, would you mind fixing the place cards for me? I'm so late. They're right in there on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Certainly, dear. (she starts into dining room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane's voice is continuing off scene as Mrs. Mason enters gives the table a critical once-over. It is set for six.

dialogues.speaker: JANE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: That girl took so long to fix my hair, I didn't get out of the place till half past six. It's still sopping wet. Mrs. Mason has picked up the place cards from the desk an crosses to table, sorting them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starts to fix place cards) You should have made an earlier appointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, fixing up before mirror, reacts to this implied criticism.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (grimly) Yes, I should. (she rouges savagely) I thought I'd put Judge Doolittle on my right, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mason is placing the cards.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Naturally.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: And Mr. Carter -- I suppose I'll have to have him on my left.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: You seem to think I've never done this before.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: No, no dear. It's just that I never have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie enters from kitchen and goes to sideboard. She open drawer to look for nut cracker.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: You have the wine glasses on the wrong side, Annie.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (resentfully) The left side was the right side where I worked before.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) The right side was the water glasses, Annie. Annie exits to kitchen in a huff, giving the swinging doo push that causes it to swing violently. Mrs. Mason takes floral center-piece off the table and brings it over to t sideboard. Jane enters from bedroom, her hair in a net an wearing a house robe.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: How do you think the table looks?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Isn't it a little crowded? Jane sees that the center-piece has been removed.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh, that girl will drive me crazy! She goes to the sideboard, takes the centerpiece and repl it on the table.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: The things that pop up at the last minute! I had to borrow some finger bowls from the woman downstairs because we only had four. (she scans the place cards) Oh -- are you at Johnny's right?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: I always have been.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I thought tonight I'd put Miss Doolittle there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh well, of course, it's your party, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (re-arranges the place cards) Just this once. Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Certainly not. (reminiscently) You know, I thought at one time that John and Eunice Doolittle --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (turns sharply) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: But there was nothing in it... Buta lovely girl!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (abruptly) Would you be a dear and see if Annie has the appetizers fixed?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Of course, dear. (she exits to kitchen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up Eunice's place card and looks at it thoughtf

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie is busy at the stove. She isn't accustomed to dinne for six and is in a violent temper.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: I think you have too many on the plate, Annie. And shouldn't they be garnished? Where's the silver tray -- the one I gave them?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: I don't know how many hands they  expect you to have in this place! There's just so much a body can do! I'm only human. Annie places tray before Mrs. Mason.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: I'll fix the canapes for you, Annie, since you seem to have so much to do. (tastes salad dressing) A little too much vinegar in your salad dressing, Annie, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: I'm only human.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (looks toward stove) Oh, your potatoes aren't going to burn, are they? I'm afraid you put them on too early. Annie slams down mixing spoon and starts savagely out of kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: AT DRESSER
dialogues.text: Jane is continuing with her dressing. The grim face of An suddenly appears in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: I'm leavin'.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (turns, horrified) You're WHAT?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Right now. You can stand just so much. I'm only human.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: But you can't do that! What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: I can't please everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (understanding reference to mother- in-law and depressed -- then frantic) Oh... But, Annie -- my guests will be here any minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the top off the soup kettle, tastes it, adds a little salt -- looks at the potatoes, adds a large hunk o butter -- opens oven, looks at roast, turns down gas jet. short, she completely edits Annie's dinner.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Well, I'll see you through dinner, but I'm leaving at nine o'clock sharp to catch the nine-thirty fairy boat to Staten Island -- an' nobody's goin' to stop me! (she exits)

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (enters from bedroom, muttering under her breath) I'm only human. Mrs. Mason leaves kitchen as Annie enters it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Watch the potatoes, Annie! Annie hits the door a smack and it swings violently behin her as she enters kitchen. Jane enters from living room a proceeds toward Mrs. Mason.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (gently tactful) Dear, Annie has so much to do -- the extra guests and everything -- Don't you think we'd better humor her  tonight -- sort of leave her alone...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (crucified) You asked me to see about the canapes --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I know -- but it's a great deal for one person to do. And too many of us telling her what to do only upsets her.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (at same time) Well -- I was only trying to help. A whistle from the living room interrupts them.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: There's Johnny!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: He steps up to greet his wife and his mother, holding something concealed under his coat.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I bet you forgot the wine! Triumphantly he produces the bottle from under his coat a hands it to Jane.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Old Granite Puss's favorite brand! (kisses Jane on lips and takes off his overcoat) I called up Doolittle's club and found out -- Pretty nice, huh? (throws overcoat on hall bench and kisses his mother on forehead -- reaches over and takes bottle from Jane -- looks at it) It's Burgundy and it sparkles! (hands it to his mother) Tell Annie to chill it, Mother. They'll be here any minute!  (to Jane) You'd better get dressed! (starts to take off coat and vest as he crosses to bedroom door, followed by Jane)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny rushes in, flings his coat on the bed, and is ripp at his tie as he starts into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: How's everything going?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Everything's lovely! An ultimatum from Annie and this one's final! She goes to the bed to pick up Johnny's coat -- his pants come flying out and drape themselves over her. The sound running water.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: She's through tonight.

dialogues.speaker: AT BATHROOM DOOR
dialogues.text: Johnny pops his head out -- quickly without even looking himself, giving himself about a seven-stroke electric sha INT.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (thunderstruck) Tonight!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: It's all right. She'll see us through dinner.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (from bathroom) I don't see why you have so much trouble with servants. Down at the office we get all the help we want. Jane closes her eyes and grits her teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to change places with you for just one day. The noise of the electric razor stops. Jane is taking Joh suit to closet. She hangs it up and comes out with differ suit.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Jane, for Pete's sake, what did you do with the witch hazel?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I didn't have it. Look on the third shelf back of the eye wash.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (grumbling) Always putting things behind things...

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (putting Johnny's suit on the bed) That was a brilliant idea of yours, asking Eunice Doolittle at the last minute! She gets her dress from closet.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: She and the judge are like corned beef and cabbage. They're always together. (he comes out in his underwear)

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (takes off her robe) And that impossible twirp, Carter -- I suppose you had to ask him, too! Johnny gets a shirt from dresser and starts putting it on

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Eunice had some sort of date with Carter. What could I do? (mumbles to himself) I not only do all that guy's work,  for him, but feed him as well. (reaches for his pants and starts getting into them -- one leg first) It's all going to be different when my name goes up on that door. Jane, getting into her dress, comes over to him. Johnny h one leg in his pants.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh, Johnny -- do you really think so?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: It's practically up there now. What's for dinner tonight?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Roast beef.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Roast beef! Doolittle's delight.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You know, I tried to have Annie make Yorkshire pudding -- but she never heard of it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Oh, that's all right. Between roast beef and Higgins against Higgins how can we lose? Yes, sir, that's going to be all right -- my name up there on the door. He starts to button his shirt. Jane assists him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (as he buttons top button) Doolittle --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (buttons second button) Messerschmidt --

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (buttons third button) Doolittle --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (buttons fourth button) Hutch --

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (buttons last button) and Mason!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh, Johnny!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Well, didn't I win my motion for a new trial in Higgins against Higgins? I had a memo from Doolittle today.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh, you did. What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: He said he couldn't have handled it better himself. And when he eats from your table tonight, he'll eat out of my hand. And will I tell Carter!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: And will we hop the Normandie!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: And will we go places!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: And will we do things! (looks at Johnny) Darling, I don't like that tie. Wear the blue one.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (starts to take off tie) Holy Mackerel.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Johnny, does your name have to be last?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, for the time being anyway. You know what it means to a man to get into a firm like that?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (squirming with her dress) You know what it means to a firm to get aman like you in it? (turns her back to him) Here, hook me up. He comes behind her to hook her.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Pretty nice neck you've got there. (kisses her on the back of the neck)

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: As nice as Eunice Doolittle's?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: What do I know about Eunice Doolittle's neck? I never even noticed she had one. (quickly changes the subject which is a slightly dangerous one -- looks at his wrist watch) Hey, do you know what time it is? Get dressed, will you?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I am dressed.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (gets into his coat) Come on then! (starts out the door) Old Granite Puss will be here any minute.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Good evening.  Johnny reacts, turns and starts toward his guests.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP IN LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Judge Doolittle standing in a group including Mrs. Mason, Carter, and Eunice, the judge's daughter. Johnny and Jane come into the scene.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (fearfully) Good evening, Judge. I've got great news for you tonight, Judge. We're having roast beef. Roast beef for dinner, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Her face grim, a large serving platter in her arms. CAMER DRAWS BACK and we see she is serving Doolittle, squeezing against him so that he is in a very awkward position. An appalling silence hangs over the table. From the conditio of the various plates, we can see it is Annie's second ti around. Doolittle manages to spear a slice. He puts it on his plate and is about to reach for another when he finds that Annie has moved on to Jane. A little bewildered, Doolittle places the serving fork and spoon on the edge o the platter. He has to reach across Jane to do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With one prong of her fork she spears the very end of a s of asparagus and pops it into her mouth -- with an expres look at Carter, as if to say: whatever made me come here tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs, sticks his tongue against his cheek, looks ceilingward and makes cabalistic marks on the tablecloth with the end of his knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ignores her food and beats with her finger tips on th edge of the table. She seems to be nursing some secret grievance and stewing about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He saws away at a piece of meat that is making a bum out his knife. He gives up and leans forward with a gesture o his hand as if he is about to make a desperate effort to renew the conversation -- but the effort is abortive. He finds he has nothing to say.

dialogues.speaker: JANE AND DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: She turns to Doolittle.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (rather loudly, in deference to Doolittle's deafness) Would you care for some more wine, Judge Doolittle?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Yes. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (to Annie, at other end of table) Annie -- more wine for Judge Doolittle.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (loudly) There ain't any more. Doolittle decides to start on his salad. He can't find a salad fork. With a crucified expression, he uses his meat fork. Annie starts toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (sharply) A salad fork for Judge Doolittle, Annie!

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (as she exits into kitchen) I put one there. The swinging door closes behind her.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (desperately tries to  change the subject) Funniest thing happened to me the other day, Judge Doolittle -- I ran across the year book of my husband's class at college, and in the class prophecy he was picked out as the one most likely to succeed.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (louder) The other day I ran across the year book of my husband's class at college, and in the class prophecy --

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, yes -- yes.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Higgins against Higgins was quite an important case, wasn't it, Judge Doolittle?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: We like to think all our cases are important. The little client of today may be the big client of tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: Oh, you're so right, Judge.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: For instance, we got a client the other day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie has been serving the dessert. She sets a plate of a liquid ice cream before the Judge. He stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh dear -- (at the breaking point,  but trying desperately to control herself) What happened to your ice cream, Annie? Annie continues serving the ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: I told you to have the ice box fixed. She puts a piece of paper alongside Jane's plate. Jane lo at the note.

dialogues.speaker: THE NOTE
dialogues.text: It reads: "I've got to leave. I want my pay. $12.00."

dialogues.speaker: THE TABLE
dialogues.text: Annie is standing near Jane. Jane hands her the note and whispers to her.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (whispering to Annie) Annie, give this note to Mr. Mason. Annie departs with note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks across the table and tries to mouth the import Annie's message to Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He mouths back inquiries. He can't make out what Jane is trying to convey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking from Jane to Johnny, wondering what's going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane gives up and turns to Doolittle.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Johnny Is it true, Judge Doolittle, something new is going to happen in the firm this week? by this time has gotten the significance of the note. He rises and starts out. Johnny

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (to Doolittle) Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, please? exits. Doolittle continues.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Oh yes -- we're going to have a blood transfusion... I'm only speaking metaphorically of course. What I mean is we're getting some new blood into the firm -- appointing a junior partner.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh! She looks frantically toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You couldn't stay and serve the coffee, could you Annie?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Here's seven dollars -- and I'll send you --

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (adamant -- in a loud voice) I want my twelve dollars now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering and trying to shush her) All right, Annie -- all right. I'll get it for you. I'll get it -- maybe. Turns to go out.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: That's how to keep an old firm young. I've been doing this every five years and it's quite a job to pick the right man. Johnny comes out of the kitchen. Doolittle frowns at the interruption.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Johnny --

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (as he passes the table) Excuse me -- (he proceeds to the living room)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (answering Doolittle) I shouldn't think so. Surely it's a question of merit --

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: He rummages through Jane's bureau drawer -- stockings and handkerchiefs falling out, etc... finds her purse, takes a small roll of bills, closes the purse, restores it to i place.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: As a rule I always trust my own judgment, but when it comes to picking men --  Johnny enters from the living room.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Johnny --

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Excuse me -- He exits again into the kitchen. Doolittle is more annoyed than ever at the continuous interruptions.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (continues) ...I think there's nothing like a woman's intuition.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: Oh, you're so right, Judge.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Of course, Eunice doesn't know much about law -- but she's traveled all over the world and she does know people. Five years ago it was at her suggestion that I took Mr. Hutch into the firm. It worked out so well... Johnny enters from the kitchen and takes his place at the table.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon -- I'm very sorry...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (continues his speech) ...that this year I have again consulted my daughter. And now a new name moves up on the door of our offices. (Johnny and Jane listen eagerly) Beginning next Monday, the name of the firm will be -- Doolittle --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting expectantly for Doolittle to announce the new fi member.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Messerschmidt -- Doolittle -- Hutch -- and Carter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reacts in keen disappointment. She looks across the t at Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trying to rise to the occasion, he stands...

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Well, Carter -- Congratulations! It's wonderful. I always knew you had it in you... I'd like to propose a toast to the new partner -- only -- we -- seem to have run out of -- wine. There isn't any more wine. His voice cracks on the last word and he sinks to his cha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at Johnny trying to smile -- the tears running down her face.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: Upon which is written:

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANGHAM
dialogues.text: CAMERA DRAWS BACK as the door opens and Jane comes out -- excited, starry-eyed, almost cross-eyed with the import o news she has just received from the doctor. CAMERA PANS w her and she goes to a desk at which is seated a nurse, bu engaged with filing cards.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (tremulously)  May I have some paper and an envelope, please?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Certainly. She hands Jane a sheet of office stationery and an envelo

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Thank you. CAMERA PANS Jane over to a little writing desk. She sits down, reaches for the pen and draws a large heart in the center of the sheet. In her excitement she begins to hum "Columbia, The Gem of the Ocean" as she starts to write a note within the heart.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Would you like a stamp?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: No thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JANE AT WRITING DESK
dialogues.text: Humming and writing. She looks up.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Could I have a safety pin, please?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Surely. She comes into the Shot and puts a safety pin on the desk

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Thank you. Nurse exits. Jane fixes the safety pin on the note she ha just written, folds the note, encloses it in the envelope and writes furiously on envelope. She seals the letter an rises. CAMERA PANS with her as she starts to exit. The nu amused, turns to watch her leave. As Jane disappears thro the door --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANNING with him as he paces before the jury box. meet a new and startlingly different Johnny. He may be a worm to Doolittle -- a schnook to Jane -- and Little Lord Fauntleroy to his mother, but here he is in his element - the flaming advocate, concluding his eloquent summation t the jury in a burst of forensic fireworks.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: And I tell you, gentlemen of the jury, the defendant Higgins, with unbrotherly venom and motivated solely by a desire maliciously and hatefully to interfere with his brother's rights and privileges --

dialogues.speaker: THE JURORS
dialogues.text: The foreman is consulting a time table.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: -- deliberately and improperly diverted the waters of the stream --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Featuring schedule of trains to Long Island. The foreman' finger is running down a list of trains. Now the train af the four o'clock is circled.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (fervently) Well, gentlemen, I leave the determination of these matters in your hands, confident that your verdict will bring justice to my client, the plaintiff in this action. Johnny wipes his brow and subsides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes to with a start from something very closely approximating a nap and shakes his head to clear his drow wits.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Gentlemen of the jury --

dialogues.speaker: JURORS
dialogues.text: The foreman's face puckered with anxiety as he looks at t table.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You will now retire to arrive ata verdict. The jury starts to file out of the jury box.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Seated at counsel table making notes. A bailiff comes ove and whispers in his ear. Johnny's face lights up and he t and looks toward the other end of courtroom. He rises and waves joyously -- then starts eagerly out of Shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last row of seats in courtroom. Jane is seated there. Joh comes into scene and she moves over one seat to make room for him. He drops into the seat alongside and puts his ar around her waist.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I came in just as you started your summation, Johnny -- it was wonderful!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You should have been here when I cross-examined Higgins.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Your Higgins?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: No -- the other one.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (passing through scene) You skinned him alive.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I tore him apart! I really cut him up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny -- She hands him an envelope. He grins at her and looks at i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Dr. Langham's stationery and marked:

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY AND JANE
dialogues.text: Johnny opens the letter and reads it. Jane is watching Jo with bated breath. Johnny's eyes open wide as he reads th letter and begins to gather its import.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instead of one heart-shaped enclosure, there are two join together by the safety pin. Within the large heart is wri "The party of the second part wishes to announce to the p of the first part that we're going to be in the market fo lot of these for the -- Here a curved arrow points to the safety pin. Within the small heart is written: Party of the third part."

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY AND JANE
dialogues.text: Johnny looks up at Jane. He is speechless with surprise a joy. He tries to say something but his bobbing Adam's app prevents speech.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (suddenly shouting) Jane! He takes her into his arms. Three men come into the shot.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST MAN
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Mason!

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MAN
dialogues.text: Good work!

dialogues.speaker: THIRD MAN
dialogues.text: You did a swell job!

dialogues.speaker: A TABLET
dialogues.text: It reads: MANHATTAN MATERNITY HOSPITAL

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Asleep in bed. He has taken a room next to Jane's in the hospital. A blinking Neon sign from outside window is fla in his face. CAMERA MOVES BACK as he moves restlessly and suddenly awakes with nightmarish movements. Stupefied wit sleep, he fumbles with clock on bedside table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It indicates a few minutes to four o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL ROOM
dialogues.text: Johnny leaps out of bed, still more asleep than awake, ta another look at the clock, then quickly comes to life. He blunders into his bathrobe and slippers, putting on the f as he exits room.

dialogues.speaker: AT DOOR
dialogues.text: As Johnny, still half asleep, comes into the hall. CAMERA PANS with him to adjoining room. Johnny listens, hears no he knocks softly on door, gets no answer, hesitates and t softly opens the door. Looks into the room.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOM
dialogues.text: It is brightly lit. CAMERA MOVES UP to the bed. It is emp but not made up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes in the significance of the empty bed and registe  accordingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny streaks away from his wife's room and runs down th corridor. As he reaches end of corridor;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It opens and Johnny, wild-eyed, pops in. A nurse walks in the scene and bars his further progress.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Is it -- happening?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: It's happening.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Why didn't they wake me? I want to be with her -- I've got a right to be with my wife, haven't I?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: (a little impatiently) All right. Wait a minute. You can't go in there until you put this on. He waits, tremblingly -- looking toward the opposite door The nurse comes back with surgical gown and mask. She hel him with the garment and mask. He keeps looking toward th opposite door.

dialogues.speaker: OPPOSITE DOOR
dialogues.text: The door swings open for a moment as another nurse comes of the delivery room. A quick glimpse of the activity ins before the door swings shut.

dialogues.speaker: ANTEROOM
dialogues.text: Johnny enters, walks toward operating table.

dialogues.speaker: UP
dialogues.text: Jane sees Johnny and is just barely able to smile, makes weak effort to say, "Hello."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His lips move under the mask with answering greeting.

dialogues.speaker: ANAESTHETIST
dialogues.text: -- as he prepares ether mask.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: He has picked up Jane's hand and we get the reaction of t ether on her from the manner in which her hand droops out his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: across Johnny's back as he steps away from table -- beyon can be seen doctor and anaesthetist's activity - but John body covers view of Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reacts to activity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurses -- Doctor -- Assistants -- Busy expert hands handi such instruments as may be permissible to doctor, etc. Over these Shots -- low and indistinguishable -- come the various voices of Doctor, Nurses and other appropriate so There are, however, no sounds of pain as Jane is under ha ether.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reacts to activity.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY'S EYES
dialogues.text: In the eyes is double printed the activity in the deliver room.

dialogues.speaker: DELIVERY ROOM
dialogues.text: Johnny in foreground blocking out Jane's body. We get a glimpse of the doctor and nurse as obstetrician holds the newborn baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he holds the baby up by the feet. The obstetrician is slapping the baby's feet. It emits a tiny squeak.

dialogues.speaker: OBSTETRICIAN
dialogues.text: Come on -- you can do better than that. (slaps the baby's feet again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: watching -- his eyes almost popping out of his head. Into the Shot comes the querulous wail of the newborn babe.

dialogues.speaker: OBSTETRICIAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Atta boy!

dialogues.speaker: FROM JOHNNY'S POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: Activity around operating table. It starts to go out of f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slips to the floor in a dead faint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hospital bill with itemized account of hospital expense made out to John H. Mason. Cashier's hand comes into Shot and stamps a paid rubber stamp form on bill.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Now he's all yours, Mr. Mason. CAMERA DRAWS BACK as we see Johnny standing in front of  cashier's cage. Cashier hands Johnny the bill.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (as he looks at bill) All mine.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Come in again some time.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Thank you -- I will. (he starts to go, then realizing the import of her remark, stops for a moment, embarrassed) I mean I -- yeah. (he exits precipitously

dialogues.speaker: CORNER
dialogues.text: As the traffic sign goes to "Stop" for 5th Avenue traffic 5th Avenue bus, a carriage, a taxi and a truck pull up an stop. In f.g., is a mounted policeman directing traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light turns to "Go" for 5th Avenue. LONG SHOT - FIFTH AVENUE CORNER (as before) Traffic stands immovable -- cars behind start honking -- people on bus, coachman, truck driver, etc., still lookin down into taxi. Irate cop gallops over towards taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across roof of taxi as cop rides into scene.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: (bawling at driver) Hey! What do you think you're doing holding up traffic? He suddenly looks down and his expression changes to a br  grin.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Oh... What is it, boy or girl?

dialogues.speaker: JANE AND JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Jane is holding the baby. Johnny grins proudly. Johnny's expression.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: The cop smiles, understanding. The horns honking and blowing again. Cop turns and after the impatient honkers.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Hey, cut that out! wake that baby! going. Do you want to All right -- get Traffic starts to move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny curiously embarrassed; Jane proud. indifferent.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Johnny?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Uh huh --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (softly) Like him?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (sheepish grin -- trying very hard to conceal his memotion) Sort of.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Don't you think he's... he's just Jane indicates start furiously starts furiously The baby alone is  beautiful?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (dodging the question) He... he looks old, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Old? What do you mean, old?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I mean... he looks as though he were six months old -- or a year -- at least.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh, Johnny, you're silly... but don't you think he's just beautiful?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (dodging) I hope he grows up to look like you.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: How can he? He has all your features.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I don't see how you can tell that by looking at that face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who looks like no one on earth.

dialogues.speaker: JANE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Just look at the way his eyes crinkle... Just the way yours do when you're happy.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: He doesn't look happy. He looks kind of bored.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Well, you'd be bored too, if you'd been through what he has... But don't you think he's just beautiful? Johnny has put out his hand. The baby has gripped his fi INSERT: Baby's finger gripping Johnny's

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Boy, what a grip!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (tenderly) But don't you think he's just beautiful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OPEN on CLOSE SHOT BABY in portable canvas babies' bath s up in bathroom. Jane's hands are sponging the baby.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Well, fella, how do you like your first bath? CAMERA DRAWS BACK to reveal Jane, in house gown giving th baby its first bath at home. Johnny, in shirt sleeves, is sitting on the edge of the tub, fascinated. Mrs. Mason st alongside watching and coaching. The advent of the baby h materially changed the appearance of the bathroom. A clothesline is rigged across the room and on it hang thre diapers held by clothespins. A baby's scale sets on the closed seat of the toilet, or a clothes hamper or etc. Jane handles the baby very ginge

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Be sure you soap his head thoroughly. It prevents cradle-cap.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (still pleasantly) Yes, Mother. I know.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (more baby talk to baby)  Ittie Johnny doesn't want nasty old cradle-cap, does oo?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Look at those shoulders! Can I do something Jane? (pleadingly) Please! He reaches for baby as Jane lifts him out of the water. T movement makes Jane almost let it slip through her hands she exclaims in fright:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (panicky) Now look what you've done! I almost dropped him! Do move over, Johnny -- please! Her back to CAMERA, she holds the baby in her arms as she pulls over the canvas top of the tub and lays the baby on it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: If you'd let me show you how --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (not quite so pleasantly) I know how. They showed me at the hospital. (she is now drying the baby, her back still to CAMERA)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: You don't rub the baby dry. You just pat him.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (beginning to wear thin) I am patting him.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: He looks red. Maybe the water was too hot.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) No, Mother. It was just right. I tested it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (to baby in baby talk) Was its 'ittle water too hot for ittie Johnny?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (she turns to Johnny) Johnny, will you hand me his shirt? Johnny reaches for the wrong garment.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Not that one! This one. She gets the shirt, starts to put it on.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (admiringly) Look at the chest on him! (eagerly) Can't I help? Neither woman pays any attention to him.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Be careful of his little head, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (still pleasantly) I will, Mother. Johnny, you'd better go in the kitchen and warm his milk. PAN WITH JOHNNY as he starts out of the room. He almost collides with the clothesline and has to stoop in order t get by it; almost knocks over the scales as he exits.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (calling to Johnny Not too hot, John!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: The baby is now all dressed for the night, and Jane has h safely cradled in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fervently) Hallelujah! (with great sigh of relief) He's bathed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
