dialogues.text: Mrs. Mason stands over the crib. Jane is wearily stretche out in a chair near the crib, her arms and legs stretched fatigue, her eyes closed: the mother just back from the hospital. The baby is crying lustily. They look harassed.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: A touch of colic.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (without opening her eyes -- wearily) No, Mother, he's just hungry.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (with maddening tolerance of her daughter-in-law's stupidity) I'm sorry, my dear, but it's colic... He's been crying for five minutes. Jane closes her eyes and controls herself with effort.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (sitting up a little, calling impatiently) Johnny! Where's that bottle! Johnny comes in from kitchen, triumphantly carrying the b bottle.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (goes toward the crib) Here, fella -- the feed bag!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY AT CRIB
dialogues.text: The baby still squawling -- Johnny trying to put the bot into its hands.

dialogues.speaker: BABY
dialogues.text: Baby's hands fighting off bottle, as he continues to bawl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane comes into scene. She yanks the bottle from Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: They don't eat with their hands, you dope! She rolls up her sleeve and tests the temperature of the milk by spilling a few drops on her forearm, looking at J in a superior manner and shaking her head. She lowers the bottle toward the crib.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jane forces the bottle into its mouth. His squawling c instantly and he sucks the nipple with vehement appreciat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again Jane goes to chair and sinks down wearily. The door rings. Johnny exits to answer it. Jane looks at the conte baby, then speaks to Mrs. Mason:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (lies back in her chair, closes her eyes) You see Mother, he was hungry.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: If he were fed on time he wouldn't cry.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (Her eyes still closed, her hands tighten on the arm of the chair) As soon as we're organized...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (interrupting)  Too bad he has to be fed on a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (sighs -- grimly) I haven't heard the baby complain yet.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: John never saw a bottle till he was six months old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Controlling herself, speaks as inaudibly as possible -- practically to herself:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (as she speaks she clenches her hands on the arms of the chair) I won't say anything. I won't say anything. I won't say anything...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: What's that, my dear?

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Johnny comes in -- carrying a flat, small package already half unwrapped.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: What do you think? It's a present from old Granite Puss... He sits down beside Jane, starts unwrapping the package.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I'll bet it's a summons.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: No -- it's a bank book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny's hands finishing opening package. It contains a b book showing that an account has been opened in the name John H. Mason, Jr, with an opening deposit of $10.00 -- a  accompanying it is Judge Doolittle's business card. Johnny's hand turns the card over. On it is handwritten: "A penny earned is a penny saved."

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: He's deposited Ten Dollars. (he hands Jane the open bank book.) Mrs. Mason glances over Jane's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Say -- that's a lot of money for the little guy.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I hope it doesn't plunge Doolittle into bankruptcy.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: After that hospital bill he's got more cash in the bank than I have.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (very superior) I think it's very considerate of Judge Doolittle to think about the baby's future.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I'm not worried about his future -- It's the present that bothers me... Where are we going to put him?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Why can't he stay in our room?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You know he kept you awake last night.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (with demure over- sweetness) You should have taken that into consideration, my dear, before you  rented this apartment.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (too tired to argue) I know. I should have.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: If my own room weren't so small --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (sweetly, forgetting and forgiving what she's been through) Oh, I wouldn't think of it, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilda, the current cook, stands listening.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: We could keep him in our room days and in the living room nights.

dialogues.speaker: JANE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: That's too far from the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Well, in the dining room, then.

dialogues.speaker: JANE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It's too near the kitchen -- but I suppose we'll have to. Hilda shows that she doesn't relish the idea of the baby being near the kitchen. She coughs to attract attention.

dialogues.speaker: HILDA
dialogues.text: Mrs. --

dialogues.speaker: JANE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes, Hilda?

dialogues.speaker: HILDA
dialogues.text: (Swedish accent) Could I please see you a minute? Jane comes into the Shot.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What is it, Hilda?

dialogues.speaker: HILDA
dialogues.text: Your mother-in-law hired me when you was away -- but she didn't say why you was away --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (tight-lipped) You mean you don't approve of my having a baby?

dialogues.speaker: HILDA
dialogues.text: That's your business. You can have as many babies as you like.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (grimly) Thank you. That's big of you.

dialogues.speaker: HILDA
dialogues.text: But my business is cooking. You get somebody else to wash the diapers. She turns and starts to exit. Jane calls after her, almos tearfully:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You're -- (with a wail) you're fired! Hilda pays no attention to this parting sally but continu her march across the room. Hear Johnny's Voice as Jane turns back into room:

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (talking to baby -- very cheerful, oblivious to all the agony) Don't you worry, Johnny -- FOLLOW JANE AS SHE GOES BACK INTO THE LIVING ROOM and sin again into chair, almost exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: JANE IN CHAIR
dialogues.text: Speaks softly, almost to herself:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I wish I could go back to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: CRIB
dialogues.text: Johnny talking to the baby.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: As soon as the lease is up we'll get a house in the country with a room all your own -- and a garden to ride your bicycle in, and -- (he stops suddenly, open-mouthed, and looks up at Jane and his mother) Look! Mother! Jane! Look -- the baby! He's smiling -- he's smiling at me! Mrs. Mason bends over the crib... Jane runs in to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: smiling.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (straightens and shakes her head condescendingly) That's gas!

dialogues.speaker: CLASS OF '28
dialogues.text: You'll see all the Old Faces Wednesday Evening, October 5

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL ASTOR BLUE ROOM
dialogues.text: Make Your Reservations Now!! Over this comes the sound of a clock starting to strike twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hall is lighted only by a dim light from the living r The sound of the clock striking continues. The sound of a key turning in the lock, the door opens, and Johnny enter He is in dinner clothes, black overcoat, and scarf. He se unusually dejected. He softly closes the door behind him starts on tiptoes toward the bedroom, CAMERA TRUCKING WIT HIM. Attracted by the light from the living room, he stop in the doorway and looks in at:

dialogues.speaker: JANE ON DIVAN
dialogues.text: (from his angle) Jane, in a warm bathrobe, is curled up asleep. On the floor by the divan is an open book, face u A lamp on a nearby table is the only light in the room.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: He tiptoes into the room, taking off his hat as he crosse and sits down on the floor near the divan, looks at Jane moment, moody and licked. Then he notices the open book o the floor. He puts his elbows on his knees, cups his chin and stares at the open book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a year book of Johnny's college, open at the page bearing Johnny's picture. Over Johnny's picture, the word "Class of 1928" and under Johnny's picture: "Most Likely to Succeed" JOHN HORACE MASON

dialogues.speaker: DIVAN
dialogues.text: Jane stirs and opens her eyes, sees Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from Jane's angle) Unaware Jane has awakened, his expres still moody and despondent, staring at the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From her expression we know that now she understands John mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smiling, Jane sits up, puts her arms around Johnny and ki him.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: How was it, Johnny?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Oh, swell.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Who was there?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Oh, just the same old crowd, only ten years older.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Who spoke, Johnny?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Ed O'Malley made quite a speech -- all about how he bought that seat on the stock exchange. And then Joe Kendall -- just got back from opening up a London office --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Did you make a speech?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You know -- the things you have to say at a reunion. Nothing much.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (insists)  What did you say, Johnny?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Well, my speech was pretty short. What would I have to say? (bitterly -- Johnny sees book on the floor) The man most likely to succeed.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Well, I think you have and I bet your speech was swell. (they kiss) Did you tell them that funny story you told me yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: No -- no, I didn't think of it. All I could think of was my achievements -- What I've accomplished and how far I've gone. I suppose I should have told them how I used your money -- all of it -- to buy the furniture for this apartment.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Now, that's silly. Your money -- my money -- what's the difference? It wasn't much anyway.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I should have told them how the baby has to sleep in the dining room --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Well, what of it? And it's only temporary -- till we get a new apartment --

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (over Jane's dialogue) -- because I can't afford to get you a decent place to live --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Stop it! Don't say those things! Sometimes I get so mad at you I can't see straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I get so mad at myself I can't see at all!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I know what happened -- the dinner disagreed with you. What did you have?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I don't know -- I didn't eat any of it.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Now I know what's wrong -- you're hungry! (she rises, grabs his arm and yanks him up) C'mon, honey, I'll get you something out of the ice box. (she starts to pull him from the living room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny and Jane enter. Jane proceeds to the ice box, open it and starts to pry into it, taking things out.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Now let's see. Here's some cheese you like. And a whole cold chicken staring us right in the face. Which?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Chicken. Jane takes the platter and puts it on the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: The trouble with you is you let people step on you! You do all the work in that office... Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: No. Milk. Jane takes milk from the ice box and sets it on the tabl

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You've forgotten more about law than Carter'll ever know. How do you expect people to recognize your value if you don't recognize it yourself?... White or rye?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Rye. She goes to bread box -- rummages in it.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: They couldn't get along without you for one minute -- and you know it! Everybody knows it! She gets bread knife and starts to butter bread.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (eats a leg of chicken) Everybody but Doolittle.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: He knows it too! But he takes advantage of you. I told you when he promoted Carter over your head that you should have quit -- walk right out on him!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Now, Jane, how could I? What about --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I know -- your mother and I. I wish you'd forget about us.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: If I lost my job --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: But you wouldn't! They'd never let you go! You're far too valuable! If you left, Doolittle would crawl to you on his hands and knees and beg you to come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wry laugh) On his hands and knees! You don't know Doolittle.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I know you! All you've got to do is speak up -- stand right up to Doolittle! Don't ask for your rights -- demand them! He reaches for her hand and looks at the simple wedding b on one finger.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Remember the day in Boston when I got you this ring -- I promised to get you a better one later?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I don't want a better one later.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You liked the platinum one with the diamonds.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: That can wait.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: And the mink coat can wait too, I suppose. Probably in about three hundred years I can afford to buy you one.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What are you -- a man or a mouse?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: A mouse! Jane grabs the kitchen knife and waves it in front of Joh as she talks:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: John Mason, you know what's the matter with you? You're too modest. You don't appreciate yourself... I do  want that platinum ring! And I want a fur coat -- not the mink -- but a fur coat! And I want a honeymoon on the Normandie! And I want an apartment that's big enough for your mother and the baby -- so the baby wouldn't have to sleep in the dining room! You can get them for me! You can get everything I want -- everything that's coming to me! But first you've got to get what's coming to you!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: If I only knew how to go about it --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: It's easy.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You think it's easy.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You just walk right into the office and you say --

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Jane, you don't walk into Judge Doolittle's office. He sends for you.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Well, this time you walk in. You go right up to him and you say: "Judge Doolittle, there's something I've got to say to you right now."

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You can't talk to him like that though.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Have you ever tried?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Now Jane, you don't understand. If I barged in there like that he'd -- he'd --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: He'd say -- "What is it Mason? Sit down."

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: He never asked me to sit down in his life.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Well then stand up. But don't let him interrupt you. Speak your piece.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yeah -- well now that -- speak your piece. It's easy to do here in the kitchen. You get downtown...

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Well, downtown or uptown, what difference does it make? You're not asking a favor of him. You're demanding your rights. He'll listen. Make him listen.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: All right -- okay -- all right -- what'll I say? Jane has been gathering up the foodstuffs. She shoves wha left of the chicken into the ice box, turns out the light and they start out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You'll say --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane and Johnny enter and start through to entry hall.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (continuing) "Judge Doolittle, I've been working for you now for five years and I've given you everything that's in me -- every ounce." They stop at the crib, look down at the sleeping baby. Du the rest of the scene Jane changes the baby's diaper as t talk. Johnny is still chewing on the leg of chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, all right -- what'll he say?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: There's no doubt about it, Mason. I've never questioned your ability or your loyalty --

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: And I'll say --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Judge Doolittle -- what're you going to do about it?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I hate to think what he'll say!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: He'll say: Mason, what do you expect me to do? And you'll say: The right thing, Judge Doolittle... I want more money and I want to be taken into the firm! And he'll say:

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: He'll say plenty!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: No matter what he'll say -- you'll say: Jane has finished changing the baby. With a last fond loo she turns and starts into the bedroom, Johnny following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane and Johnny enter. Jane still talking.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (speaking as if she were addressing Judge Doolittle in person) Judge Doolittle, I either get a raise and a junior partnership or else -- (Johnny waits breathlessly) Or else you can accept my resignation, effective immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with grim determination) Effective immediately. That's all right, Jane. That's a good idea. I'm going through with it -- one of these days.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: One of these days is tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (aghast) Tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Tomorrow morning at ten o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Well -- if you think I should!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (vehement) There's no time like the present.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (gulps) Let's start at the beginning, Jane. I'll walk into his office and I'll say --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Judge Doolittle, there's something I've got to say to you right now!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (waving his shoe at his reflection in the mirror) Judge Doolittle, there's something I've got to say to you right now!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Either I get a raise and a junior partnership --

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Either I get a raise and a junior  partnership --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Or you can accept my resignation --

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Or you can accept my resignation -- (without Jane's cue) Effective immediately.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (tenderly and proud) Effective immediately!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Not bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An alarm clock on the night table next to Johnny's bed. I registers shortly before three a.m. CAMERA PANS over to J She is asleep. She wakes suddenly and looks over toward Johnny's pillow, sees that it's empty, then attracted by sound, looks toward window.

dialogues.speaker: AT WINDOW
dialogues.text: Silhouetted in the moonlight is a figure in pajamas. It i Johnny, gesticulating fiercely, rehearsing in a sibilant whisper.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I've been working in this office for the last five years and there's something I want to tell you right now -- Either I get a raise anda junior partnership -- Or else...

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (repeats, tenderly) Or else -- (she smiles and closes her eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OPEN on CLOSE SHOT pieces of scratch paper littering John glass-topped desk, covered with scribbled designs and вЂњdoodlings." A hand comes into Shot and draws four larg exclamation points on one of the pieces of paper. (Under the glass top are many snapshots of Jane and the b in various poses.) CAMERA DRAWS BACK, and we reveal that it is Johnny who ha been sitting at his desk scribbling. He throws his pencil down and rises; starts to pace up and down the room nervo He mumbles to himself, rehearsing the speech he is going make to Judge Doolittle:

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (pacing) +..a raise and a junior partnership -- or else... The fusty old bookkeeper pokes his head in the door and J looks up, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
dialogues.text: (motioning) Judge Doolittle is in.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Okay! The bookkeeper exits. Johnny starts on another quick mumb rehearsal, pacing again.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (mumbling, then) -- Or else you can accept my resignation -- effective immediately.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: (appearing in doorway) What is it, a jury case? Johnny whirls, guiltily and embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Now, never mind. I'm thinking.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: (holds out papers to Johnny) Here are the papers in City against Consolidated. Johnny takes the papers without answering.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: I want you to drop over to Consolidated and see their accountants.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Okay. Carter goes down the corridor, just missing a collision w the office boy who pops his head in at Johnny's door.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE BOY
dialogues.text: (to Johnny) Pssst! (imitates Doolittle by flipping back his coat and motions back toward Doolittle's office with his thumb) He just got in.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Okay -- okay. As he pops out again, Johnny looks haggard and gulps. He stands motionless a moment, then in frantic hurry starts straighten his tie. He lays the papers on his desk, walks quickly to the door, and puts his hand on the knob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny stands there, gets a grip on himself and knocks timidly. Of course there is no response. Doolittle couldn possibly have heard the knock. He knocks again, just as softly, and hearing no answer, turns and is about to go b to his office when Doolittle's voice comes through the do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bellows) Come in!

dialogues.speaker: AT DESK
dialogues.text: Doolittle is frowning over some papers in his hand. Johnn stalks into the Shot, blurts out his rehearsed speech.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Judge Doolittle, there's something I've got to say to you right now -- Doolittle is intent on the Income Tax statement. Johnny c gently.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Judge Doolittle -- (Doolittle looks up) I've been working in this office --

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Oh, it's you! (grimly) You're just the one I wanted to see. (indicates a chair by his side) Sit down. Johnny, surprised at the unexpected invitation, sits on t edge of the chair and waits. Doolittle leans back in his swivel chair, adjusts his glasses and rocks slowly, fixin basilisk gaze on Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Mason --

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You've been doing mighty good work lately. Johnny smiles. The old man is actually going to make it e for him!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Johnny Johnny Johnny Thank you, Judge.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You've been capable, dependable and loyal -- right from the start! is so tickled he actually crosses his legs.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (his chest comes out a little) That's mighty nice of you, Judge!

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: But, Mason -- these are extraordinary times -- For all of us! uncrosses his legs.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Some of our biggest clients are affected. They all complain they're practically working for the Government. is rigid in his chair again.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Most of them claim it'll be all they can do to stay in business till the next election. So they're cutting expenses right and left -- and we're the first to feel it. Naturally we have to do something about it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (with sinking heart) Naturally.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (flips open his coat) What?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (repeats, louder) Naturally!

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I don't want to cut down the personnel  of my staff if I can possibly help it. -- Wouldn't be constructive. So the only way out -- as I can see it -- is to tighten our belts. I'm asking everyone to take a twenty-five percent cut. I'm starting by taking a substantial cut in my own personal drawing account. It's a sacrifice, but it hits all of us. These are days of sacrifice!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I know, Judge, but I --

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: These are times when we all have to put our shoulders to the wheel -- if we're to survive!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, our shoulders to the wheel -- Only I --

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I'm glad you understand, Mason -- I appreciate your cooperation.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (miserably) Thank you, sir. Doolittle's phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (reaches for phone) Hello -- (glances up at Johnny) Excuse me, Mason. Johnny rises and starts out. We hear Doolittle continuing into telephone:

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Hello, Commissioner. -- You know that little piece of property on Park Avenue? Well -- if the price is right --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny comes out, his face a mask of doom as he starts ba to his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny enters. We can see at once that our hero has sough comfort and slight consolation in the grape. He has had a few drinks and his courage has obviously been falsely bolstered by the liquor. He is slightly tight but in no s drunk. He glares defiantly ahead, then slams the door violently shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slamming of the door awakes Mrs. Mason and she sits quickly up as if she were goosed.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Making as much noise as possible, Johnny goes into the li room, turns on the switch which lights the central lighti fixture, and goes from lamp to lamp turning them all on. Then he stomps into the dining room, still making as much noise as possible, turns on all the dining room lights, a stomps on out to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: AT CRIB IN DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: The baby wakes up and lets out a yelp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane hears the baby cry and gets out of bed, exiting towa dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny opens the ice box, brings out a bottle of milk and starts pouring it into a glass. The bottle falls to the f with a crash. The door opens a crack and Lily sticks her head out.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Did you want something, Mister Mason?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: No thank you, Lily. Lily's head disappears.

dialogues.speaker: AT CRIB
dialogues.text: Jane quiets the baby. In a minute Johnny comes out of the kitchen, not bothering to turn out the lights after him. hat and coat are still on. His overcoat swings open and w see his suit and coat splattered with milk. He looks at J defiantly.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (belligerent) Well?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (still bending over the crib -- very casually) Good morning, Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (explosively) Good morning. (he exits toward bedroom, Jane following)

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I feel fine! (he flings his hat across the room) They go into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they enter, Johnny takes off both his overcoat and his suit coat at the same time and lets them slip to the floo Jane goes to the mirror, casually fixes her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it? Johnny flings down his vest.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (in a mounting voice -- each hour louder) Three o'clock! Four o'clock! Five o'clock! High noon! (takes off his tie and throws it down)

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (very quietly against his obviously synthetic rage) It's just two, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: If you know the time why do you ask me? What difference does it make what time it is? (starts to take off his shirt) I feel fine. He flings his shirt to the floor and exits to bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny enters -- bumps into the line of diapers, angrily rips down the cord and the diapers fall to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: JANE IN BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Now the sound of running water from the bathroom. Jane lo toward the bathroom with lowered lids, shakes her head, thinking what to do. Johnny's pants come flying into the room. Jane thinks a moment, then exits toward entry hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane goes to light switch, puts out central chandelier li then goes from lamp to lamp, putting out all the lights J lit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her light is now on. She is sitting up in bed listening w an expression of rage on her face. Finally she turns the light out viciously and sinks back into bed to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Now in pajamas at sink. He is filling a glass with mouth wash. He starts to gargle -- he gargles very loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane enters and starts to pick up Johnny's clothes. Johnn loud gargling comes from the bathroom. Jane neatly folds Johnny's clothes and starts to hang them up in clothes cl as Johnny enters and goes directly to bed, pulling blanke over him. We do not see Johnny's feet in this scene.

dialogues.speaker: JANE AT CLOSET
dialogues.text: She carefully hangs up Johnny's clothes.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Feel better now?

dialogues.speaker: AT BED
dialogues.text: Johnny curled up under blankets.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I feel fine!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Are you comfortable?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Plenty comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: JANE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Are you sure you're comfortable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finishes hanging up Johnny's things.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Certainly I'm sure I'm comfortable! Jane looks down at the figure curled up under the blanket

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (softly -- politely) Don't you think you'd be more comfortable if you took off your shoes?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Johnny sits upright -- flings the blankets off and stares his feet. He has forgotten to take off his shoes. He swin over and sits on the edge of the bed, bending down to tak off his shoes. His fumbling fingers have trouble with the shoe laces. Jane enters.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Can I help you? (she gets down on her knees)

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I don't need any help! I feel fine! But he lets her take off his shoes anyway. He suddenly explodes into an indignant tirade against nothing in particular.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (waving his arms as Jane takes off his shoes) What time is it? Am I comfortable? How do I feel? You'd think I committed some sort of crime! You'd think I was on the witness stand! A man comes home looking for a little peace and quiet, and what happens? Blah-blah- blah! Why didn't I call you back? Why didn't I come home for supper? A million questions just because a man --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (without looking up,  speaks matter-of- factly) I ran into Judge Doolittle this afternoon -- after you saw him. There is a silence. She looks up to find Johnny staring a her. His face is such a mask of misery she can hardly sta it. She rises from her kneeling position, sits on the edg of the bed alongside of him, takes him in her arms and hu him tightly.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (almost a sob) Oh, Johnny -- you fool! What does it matter if you get a raise or a partnership -- or anything!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (muffled against her bosom) Oh, Jane -- I let you down! I'll always let you down! I'm no good!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (a wall of anguish) Johnny, don't say that! It was my fault for interfering. I made you do it and I'm terribly sorry... I'll never do it again... never. We don't need anything -- we've got each other and the baby -- our beautiful baby -- You're all I have and all I want -- (sobbing) -- and please -- if you feel bad I'll die!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny's head is lowered. He doesn't answer. A little pau

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Johnny, Johnny, look at me and tell me you don't feel bad! Another second's pause, then Johnny slowly lifts his head with a grimace he thinks is a smile. His eyes are wet. Ja sees his expression and starts to cry. He is completely ashamed, puts his arms around her, and attempts to comfor her.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Jane -- I don't feel bad. They hold on to each other desperately, both of them cryi all the more.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (tears rolling down his cheeks) Jane -- I don't feel bad. (as Jane sobs convulsively) I feel fine -- honest I do. They cling to each other desperately. Jane kisses his tea away.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (laughing through her sobs) Johnny, the next time you go out and get tight... you'd better take me... along with you... or I'll... I'll get a divorce...

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (abortive attempt at laughter) You'd better get a good lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (hysterical laughter) I've got a good lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny gives a sedate little burp, as we

dialogues.speaker: SHEETS OF PAPER DRIFTING DOWN THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: There are bills of all sorts -- installment furniture, ma milk, telephone bill with discontinue threat -- the bills are stamped: "Over-due" -- "Please pay up" -- "Please rem etc. Included, perhaps is a reminder of a note due from t Morris Plan Bank. The falling bills change to falling lea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over this comes the high-pitched voice of Lily.

dialogues.speaker: LILY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Keep coming -- Come on, keep coming -- Come on now. CAMERA DRAWS BACK, as we see that the baby is crawling af a little toy cat. Lily (Louise Beavers) on her hands and knees calling to the baby.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: If you want something you gotta go get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane comes into the Shot and pauses as she hears Lily's v She seems weary and downhearted, but her face lights up a she looks off scene. She carries a folded newspaper in he hand.

dialogues.speaker: LILY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: That's it -- come on now! Come on! Jane starts toward them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baby reaches the cat and grabs it as Jane comes into Shot. Lily laughs, high-pitched, as she sees Jane, and clambers to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (excitedly) Mis' Mason -- you should have seen him travel! Jane sinks wearily onto the park bench, dropping her news beside her.

dialogues.speaker: AT BENCH
dialogues.text: Lily's smile changes to a look of concern as she looks at Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is you tired?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I've been all over town. My head's splitting. Lily comes up behind her.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Lean back, and let Lily rub the back of your neck. Jane's head goes back against the capacious bosom of Lily standing behind the bench. Lily starts to rub Jane's neck with strong capable fingers. With a sigh of content Jane closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Been visitin' 'round, Mis' Mason?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (casually) Does Mr. Mason knows you's lookin' for a job?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (opens her eyes) Who says I'm looking for a job? She looks back at Lily, sees that Lily is looking at some and follows her gaze.

dialogues.speaker: FOLDED NEWSPAPER ON BENCH
dialogues.text: Opened to the "Situations Wanted" ads.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Jane realizes how Lily knows.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Lily, it isn't nice to go prying into other people's business.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: "Scuse me, Mis' Mason.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (closes her eyes again -- after a pause) Lily, you must be the fifteenth woman I've had working for me since I've been married, and you're too good to be true. You're worth your weight in gold.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (grins) That's a lot of gold.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (almost breaking You're the best woman I've ever had in the house -- just simply perfect -- and that's why it just breaks my heart to have to tell you --

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Never you mind, honey. I knows I'ma luxury. A moment's silence while Lily rubs Jane's neck.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I'd never let you go -- never -- only I --

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Shucks, honey, you ain't gettin' rid of me -- you're just gittin' me off the budget. Is the head better?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Much better... (with a wail) I'll make such a mess of things without you.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: No you won't -- you'll step right in and do the job. And it's a pretty good job, too -- a whole lot better'n you can get on the outside. Takin' care of a nice young man an' a sweet  lil' baby an' a old lady that's jes' a little persnickety -- that's 'cause she's gittin' along an' don't have nothin' to do.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I wish it were as simple as that.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (reaches down and takes Jane's hand) Lily's a lot older than you are, honey. She's done a lot o' livin' an' she's learned one thing: Never let the seeds stop you from enjoyin' de watermelon!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (cather wistfully and with slight bitterness) That's all right if you've got watermelon.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (reproachfully) Don't say dat, Mis' Mason. You got your watermelon. But you're chokin' up on all dem li'l seeds. All I say is "Spit 'em out! Spit 'em out, before they spoils your taste for the melon!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) Spit 'em out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The words: "HAPPY NEW YEAR" in blinking neon lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (New Year's Eve) The room presents a sorry contrast to the gay revelry go on outside. There is a distinct aura of let-down and depression. Sitting in an easy chair is Mrs. Mason a shaw over her shoulder, sniffing at a tube of benzedrine and q miserable from a cold. Johnny, in evening clothes, is spr on a window seat playing with the baby's toy cat, winding up and listening morosely to the music-box tune. The only sound, except for what drifts in from the celebration in street, is the tune from the music-box. Jane's wrap and Johnny's overcoat are draped over a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens her mouth, fights it a moment, then sneezes violently.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (morosely) Bless you. Another sneeze from Mrs. Mason.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (mournfully) Bless you. (she turns to Johnny) Are you sure Carter has our telephone number?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: If he hasn't he certainly has a telephone book.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Then why do you suppose he hasn't at least called up?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (sniffing) Perhaps he forgot all about it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Mother, a man doesn't invite you to a New Year's Eve party and then just forget about it.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Maybe we ought to go join him at the party.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (a little exasperated) Jane, I told you I don't know where the party is. He said he'd call for us here in his car at nine o'clock sharp.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Well, it's almost eleven now.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Isn't the party also to announce his engagement to Eunice Doolittle?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Well, perhaps he thought it might be a little awkward to have you and Jane at his engagement party.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (sharply) Now, Mother! How could it be awkward?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Awkward or not awkward -- are we going to sit here all night waiting for him? Let's call him up! Johnny drops the cat to the floor, rises and exits to out hall.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (almost as if she's talking to herself) All the same it might be awkward.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Why should it be awkward? Before Mrs. Mason has a chance to go into detail, there i the sound of a little sneeze from the direction of the di room. Jane quickly starts in that direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny viciously dialing his number. Jane passing in b.g. way to dining room. INT.

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Jane comes into Shot just as the baby sneezes again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- sneezing. He has a runny nose.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: She his She her kisses the baby on the cheek, then puts her hand over forehead, and straightens up, CAMERA PANNING WITH HER. looks off toward Mrs. Mason in the next room, presses lips together and shakes her head disgustedly. Johnny's voice drifts in from off scene as he calls Carter's house

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First Johnny enters from the hall, then Jane enters from dining room.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: They say at Carter's house he left two hours ago. We'd better forget it.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: The baby definitely has the sniffles.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (talking through her head cold) All babies have sniffles this time of the year.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: He caught his cold from you, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: That's simply ridiculous! Matter of fact, I caught my cold from the baby. He's had sniffles all day. When I took his temperature --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's when he caught your cold.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: He certainly didn't! He had no temperature.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (trying to pour oil on the troubled waters) It's all right, Johnny -- it's just the sniffles!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: I suppose I ought to stay in my room all day!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (placatingly) Now, Mother, that's silly. You don't have to do anything of the kind!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Heaven knows I try to earn my room and board by being as helpful as I can!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh, Mother, please -- it's New Year's Eve!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: It's just like any other day as far as I'm concerned. (with rising self- pity) You're both perfectly willing to leave me all alone to wait for the New Year, when perhaps it's the last New Year I'll ever see.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (holding onto his temper) Mother -- why do you keep saying things like that? There is a ring at the doorbell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Carter! Johnny exits to outer hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny comes up to the door with Jane behind him. He open the door. Lily, all togged up in New Year's Eve finery an with traces of confetti on her clothes, comes in with a l basket in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (grinning hugely) Evenin', Mister Mason!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Hello, Lily.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Happy New Year, Lily.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Happy New Year, Mis' Mason. I want to leave this with you. Lily hands Jane the basket. Jane lifts the paper and she Johnny look into the basket.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (looks up -- gratefully) Lily, you sweet old thing!

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: It's nothin' at all. I had the day off so I cooked up the chicken and the place where I work gimme de wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is looking out disapprovingly toward the hall.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Happy New Year to you all!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Happy New Year to you!  (he starts back into the living room)

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Happy New Year, Lily. Have a good time.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: All right -- goodbye. Lily exits. Jane closes door and starts back toward livin room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- as Johnny enters.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (lugubriously) That solves everything -- now we won't have to go out! We'll stay right here and celebrate. Jane now comes in carrying the basket.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (sets the basket on the arm of Mrs. Mason's chair) We'll open up the wine now and at midnight we'll have a grand feast on Lily's chicken! (pleadingly) Come on -- it's New Year's Eve -- let's have fun!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: You know I get indigestion if I eat just before I go to bed. (sighs, looks over at chicken) Maybe there'll be some left over for me tomorrow. I never did approve of Lily -- she's much too forward -- but I do miss her cooking!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (hurt) That doesn't say much for mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you'll learn, my dear. It takes time of course.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: She grits her teeth and mutters.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I won't say anything. (she reaches for a book, opens it in the middle)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Times are different now. When I was married, every well brought up girl knew something about cooking. Jane suddenly explodes, slams down the book in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (turning) Why, Jane -- what is it?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I can't cook!... I can't keep house!... I don't know how to bring up a baby!...

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Now Jane, please -- (he starts toward the two women)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: I'm sure I don't know what you're talking about!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (tense with rage) Oh yes you do! You've resented me from the first moment you saw me! You resented me because you wanted Johnny to marry Eunice Doolittle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (injured) My dear, I never said anything like that!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You've hinted it often enough!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (indignant) I've done nothing of the sort! But they were engaged.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Mother, I never was engaged to Eunice Doolittle.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Not what you'd call engaged, perhaps --

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: And even if I were, you shouldn't keep mentioning it to Jane all the time.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: I can't understand why she's so touchy about it.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Touchy! That's why you hate me!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (agonized) Jane -- will you please --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (tosses her head) No -- let her go on. She can say anything she likes -- I know my place here. I'm only a guest -- an unwelcome guest.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (tortured) For crying out loud! What's the matter with you two?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Mrs. sob, her. (shouts) Nothing's the matter with me!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: (violently) It's her house!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (placatingly) Please, Mother --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: It's not my house!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Now, Jane -- please --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: I do the best I can to help!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Now, listen.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I'm the stranger around here! Everything I say is wrong! Everything I do is wrong!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Jane -- will you --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MASON
dialogues.text: Just because I happened to mention that John and Eunice Doolittle --

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (thunderous1ly) Now stop it! BOTH of you! Mason gives him a startled look, utters an anguished and exits rapidly, slamming the door violently behind

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (turning miserably to Jane) There! You see what you made me say  to Mother!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (hotly) You said it to me too! Don't I count?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (at his wits end) Of course you count, darling -- only Mother's an old lady -- she won't be with us for very long. Why can't you get along with her?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (hysterical) Why can't she get along with me? Because she hates me! You don't know how it is -- you're at the office all day. Between taking care of the baby and the house and cooking and listening to her criticize everything I do -- I can't stand it any more! CAMERA PANS with her to bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You can only spit out so many seeds! She exits into her bedroom, with a terrific slam of the d

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: He stands a moment, defeated and miserable -- then the fl of revolt registers in his face. He looks down at the flo and sees the baby's white cat where he had previously dro it. He kicks the cat viciously across the room. CAMERA PA with him to the chair where his hat and overcoat are. He picks them up, goes to the front door and slams out. CAMERA HOLDS a minute on the empty room, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane comes out, looks around for Johnny, CAMERA PANNING w her, then calls out in alarm:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Johnny! Johnny! She looks toward the chair in hall where her wrap and Jo overcoat had been. Jane's wrap is there but Johnny's over is gone. She quickly grabs her wrap and flies to the oute door, calling as she opens it and runs out:

dialogues.speaker: TOP OF STAIRWAY
dialogues.text: Shooting down over stairway and over Jane's head. Down a flight we see Johnny, going down. Jane enters quickly, carrying wrap.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (screaming) Johnny! Johnny stops, turns and looks up.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (surly) What?

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING UP STAIRWAY
dialogues.text: -- as Jane comes galloping down, talking as she does.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Where are you going? Johnny turns away as she catches up with him and stops on step above him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know. Anywhere to get away from that wrangling.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! (she runs down the steps and joins him) Don't you want me to go with you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Well -- can't you understand a man wants to be alone once in a while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Johnny -- really I am.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (coldly) You don't have to apologize.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (hurt at his failure to respond, but really trying to help) Would you rather I didn't come with you? He doesn't answer. Jane continues pleasantly -- with a sa little smile.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: All right, Johnny. I don't mind. You go along and have a good time. (she turns and goes up a step)

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (less than half-hearted) Oh -- Come on along if you want to.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (she turns) You're sure you don't mind?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (without enthusiasm) Certainly I don't mind... Jane advances and takes his arm.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (like a little girl) We'll have a wonderful time -- you just wait and see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is crowded. Gaiety reigns. The tiny dance floor is packed with hilarious couples.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an open bottle of wine on the table and before e a glass of wine. Before each of them also a plate contain a sandwich which has not been touched. Jane and Johnny ar not looking at each other, but are pretending to be inter in the scene about them. Johnny finally meets Jane's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh, Johnny, what's happened to us?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe I pulled a dirty trick on you when I took that cinder out of your eye up in Boston.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (with her heart in her throat) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I mean -- maybe the whole thing's been a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (stunned) What -- whole -- thing?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Our marriage.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (a quiet little cry of pain) Oh, Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (words pouring out of him now) I've gotten into debt -- I've gotten nowhere at the office and I've made a household drudge out of you, just as Mother said. Jane, it hasn't worked out -- it just hasn't worked out!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (pleading) But we've never had any real trouble. Maybe a few silly little things -- things that everybody has to meet when they get married.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Maybe we shouldn't have had the baby --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (this is a real kayo for her) Oh, Johnny -- you can't be sorry about the baby?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I'm crazy about him!... And about you too! I'd die for either of you. Jane, everybody that passes this table stops and looks at you. It's because you're young and so beautiful -- your whole life ahead of you --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (pleading) Ahead of us --

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: No -- not when you're dragged down by a guy who just can't make the grade. No, I'm not going to hold you to that kind of a contract. Jane leans back in her chair. She tries desperately to se matter-of-fact.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Well -- you ought to know all about contracts. (she shrugs and fights to keep her voice steady) Well, anyway, I suppose this is what you'd call starting the New Year right! Johnny is too miserable to say anything. Jane tries to ma her smile breezy and gay. She reaches for her glass of wi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least we've finally got something we can celebrate. (she lifts her glass and her voice breaks) Well -- Happy New Year --

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Happy New Year. He clicks glasses with her. Jane sips the wine and then b her head forward to hide her face from him for an instant He looks helplessly across the table at her and is about say something when she lifts her head. Her eyes are wet b she flashes him a dazzling smile.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Want to dance, darling? They rise and start toward the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane and Johnny threading their way through the crowd tow dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They dance silently. A thunderous roll of drums comes int the Shot and all the dancers stop to turn toward the musicians.

dialogues.speaker: ORCHESTRA STAND
dialogues.text: The trap drummer plays a rolling of drums to usher in the New Year.

dialogues.speaker: CAFE
dialogues.text: A crescendo of sounds -- whistles and other noise-making devices from the outside blend with the increasing shouts yells of HAPPY NEW YEAR within the cafe. The lights go out -- a whirling crystal ball from the cei of the cafe starts to turn -- various colored flash-light play against it and cross each other, creating weird ligh effects. From above a bunch of colored balloons tumble do Everybody in the near dark starts exchanging New Year's kisses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look off at all the other revelers exchanging kisses Johnny and Jane seem to be the only ones who aren't kissi They look at each other embarrassed, and Jane, as always, takes the initiative, looks into his eyes and then kisses him tenderly. Johnny starts to put his arms around her, b doesn't. The orchestra off scene strikes up "Auld Lang Sy The people sing. Johnny and Jane, holding hands, start to sing with frantic efforts at a gaiety that they try to wr from their leaden hearts. After the first four lines, Jane can no longer control he emotions, and she turns and starts away to keep from burs into tears. The singing continues.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I think I'll go phone the house and wish the baby a Happy New Year. Johnny takes a step to follow her.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Jane -- I'll -- But Jane has disappeared in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her face in Camera) "Auld Lang Syne" still continuing. Jane fights her way quickly through the crowd, tears stre from her eyes. A hundred balloons come from the ceiling - bibulous gents stretch arms out to stop her, but she proc fighting her way up toward a telephone booth. People call to her as she presses through, but Jane pays attention. One woman, seeing the tears in Jane's eyes, ca

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Crying Jag! A happy drunk brushes past her:

dialogues.speaker: DRUNK
dialogues.text: Happy New Year, Blondie!  A man calls from a table as she passes:

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Hey Sister -- Wait a minute ---

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER MAN
dialogues.text: Hurry back, Honey! One of the balloons floats in front of Jane's face. A man hand with a cigar comes in, and pops the balloon. Serpentine and long paper whistles unfold in front of her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny edges his way past people and sits down at the tab leaden-hearted and miserable. At an adjoining table a par is in progress, singing and chattering and having a particularly good noisy time. A blonde at this table, loo over and sees Johnny. She moves her chair an inch backwar tilts it, so her face is nearly in Johnny's.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: Hey, Lonely Heart -- what's the matter? Johnny makes a feeble attempt to call back in a croaking voice.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Happy New Year! The Blonde maneuvers herself a little nearer, crooks her through Johnny's.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: All alone? C'mon over and join our party.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (desolately) Happy New Year!

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: Why're you so mad -- don't you feel good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel fine.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: C'mon, han'some, we got champagne! (she starts pulling at Johnny's arm, and turns to her companions) Look what I found! A poor little lamb lost in the storm -- alone and neglected. A chorus of hilarious greetings from the people at the ta with invitations to join them and have a drink. Johnny is resisting the efforts to make him take a seat at their ta when Jane rushes up, wild-eyed, panicky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- as Jane grabs hold of Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (hysterically) Johnny! Come quick! The baby! Johnny rises, alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Something's the matter with the baby! They rush out frantic, and we

dialogues.speaker: "AMBULANCE"
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK, and we see now that printed above the word AMBULANCE is printed also

dialogues.speaker: "ST. FRANCIS' HOSPITAL"
dialogues.text: The ambulance is lined up at the curb. Out of the sounds the New Year's Eve revelry back of this comes the startin of an ambulance siren. CAMERA PULLS BACK FARTHER as the ambulance pulls away from the curb and with the noise of siren increasing, starts away. At the same time the ambulance starts away we see a taxi pull in to take the place of the departing ambulance. As comes to a stop with a grinding of brakes, from it emerge Johnny and Jane. Fear-stricken, they look after the depar ambulance, then rush over to Doctor Healy and Mrs. Mason stand at the curb. Doctor Healy carries his satchel.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (to Mrs. Mason frantically, looking back from the ambulance) Mother! The baby! Was that --?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (to the doctor) Doctor Healy, what is it? Jane's face is agonized. Doctor Healy hesitates, looks fr her to Johnny, hating what he has to tell them:

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR HEALY
dialogues.text: (gently -- sympathetically Pneumonia!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (a moan of anguish) Oh... Over the stricken face of Jane and Johnny we hear sounds laughter and yelling and cries of "Happy New Year."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- with the words: ST. FRANCIS' HOSPITAL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK, and we see Johnny pacing up and down i front of the door. He too wears his evening clothes of th night before. The door opens and Doctor Healy comes out. Johnny comes quickly up to him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (his voice trembling) Doctor Healy --

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR HEALY
dialogues.text: Come into the office a minute. He takes Johnny's arm and leads him into an office adjoin the laboratory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Healy enters with Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR HEALY
dialogues.text: Sit down, my boy. He indicates a chair by the desk. Johnny sits down. Docto Healy goes to the desk but doesn't sit.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR HEALY
dialogues.text: You'd better get your wife.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Now, Doctor, if it's bad news I don't want her to know about it. She just couldn't stand it -- but you can tell me, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR HEALY
dialogues.text: (speaks with deep regret) Your baby has type nine Pneumoccocus with a streptoccocus complication. And I'm sorry to say that the congestion is increasing. Now, there's a serum -- a new one -- it's worked out in some cases. Without it, we don't stand a chance. With it, well, perhaps we have a ghost of a chance.  We must get some of that serum as soon as possible. Every hour counts. I don't know whether we can locate any of it in the city or not. I'm going to check up on that right away. Johnny gets to his feet and grabs the doctor by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (strangled voice) Doctor -- please don't tell my wife --

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR HEALY
dialogues.text: (gently) I won't. (picks up the phone -- speaks into it) Give me the City Health Department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are lighted. A young pharmacist in white jacke is talking over telephone.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: (into telephone) All the type 9 serum has been sent to Salt Lake. Why don't you try Johns Hopkins in Baltimore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman in laboratory smock talking over phone:

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Sorry -- we shipped all we had for the epidemic in Salt Lake City.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another man over phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, the epidemic is under control here in Salt Lake, and we can spare six 20 c.c. vials, but how are you going to get it out of here in this storm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny is ringing the doorbell and banging on the knocker the same time.

dialogues.speaker: AT DOOR
dialogues.text: Simon, the butler, comes to the door and opens it a littl to peer out at the midnight intruder. There is a blast of wind and rain as the door is shoved open and Johnny force his way into the hall. He is rain-drenched, dishevelled a almost hysterical with panic.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (breathless, panting) I've got to see Judge Doolittle right away!

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: At this hour of the morning?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You'll have to wake him up!

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: (frowning at this sacrilege) Oh -- I couldn't do that.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You've got to! He knows me -- I work for him. I've got to see him!

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but Judge Doolittle would never allow me to -- Johnny suddenly shoves the butler violently to one side starts up the stairs on the run.

dialogues.speaker: STAIRS
dialogues.text: As Johnny runs up toward the sleeping quarters above.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: (alarmed and indignant) Say, there!... Wait! Wait!... You mustn't do that!... Where're you going? Simon starts up after Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: FOREGROUND
dialogues.text: The room is dark. Judge Doolittle is asleep in the four-p bed. Through the partly open transom we see the light go on in the hall and hear the commotion made by Johnny who is try to locate Judge Doolittle's room. He has opened a door an we hear him slam it closed.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You mustn't do this!... This is outrageous! The door in background is flung open and Johnny appears. light from the hallway helps him find the hall switch in room and he pushes it. The room lights up. Johnny starts toward the bed. The figure of the frightened butler appea in the open doorway in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The judge is a heavy sleeper and the turning on of the li hasn't awakened him. Johnny comes into Shot. In the backg Simon waits, open-mouthed.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Judge Doolittle -- Doolittle stirs but doesn't waken. Johnny repeats, louder

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Judge Doolittle!  He bends down and shakes the sleeping man.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Come on -- wake up! WAKE UP!

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: He awakes and peers owlishly upward, squinting through on eye.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Judge, I'm sorry to wake you like this --

dialogues.speaker: AT BED
dialogues.text: Doolittle throws the blanket off and is revealed in pajam He swings over and sits on the edge of the bed, reaches f his glasses on the night table, puts them on and glares u at Johnny, anger creeping through his drowsiness.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: What... what is this?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I've got to talk to you right now --

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Are you drunk?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: My kid's in the hospital -- he's got pneumonia -- Doolittle cups his hand to his ear, trying to hear; looks around for his acousticon.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (not hearing) You must be drunk waking me up in the middle of the night like this -- it's outrageous! Never heard of such a thing! Johnny realizes Doolittle isn't hearing him. He looks aro spots the judge's acousticon on the night table and reach for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason, if this is your way of celebrating the New Year -- Johnny shoves the acousticon into Doolittle's hand.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (harshly) Put it on! Doolittle puts it on, outraged.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (glaring) Now Mason, you listen to me --

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (shouts) No! -- You listen to me! When you asked me to take a cut I took it -- but I shouldn't have. Because that's the reason the baby has to sleep in the dining room and --

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (beginning to doubt Johnny's sanity) What're you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: My baby's in the hospital, dying of pneumonia!

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (motions with acousticon) What?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (shouts) Dying!... Dying!... Can't you understand that?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Dying?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yes, my baby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (now comprehending) Your baby? Well, (his rage melts) Why didn't you get in touch with me sooner? I'm terribly sorry. (he gets out of bed and puts on his robe)

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I don't need sympathy -- I need serum! There isn't any in New York -- and there's none anywhere near here -- and they finally located some in Salt Lake City -- and that's two thousand miles away and every hour counts! (he is almost sobbing the words out now)

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (with utmost sympathy) Now, Mason -- be calm --

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I can't be calm -- I'll never be calm till I get the serum. And the only way to get it here is to fly it --

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (excitedly) Certainly!... Fly it!... Of course!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: But there's a terrific storm over Utah -- all planes are grounded -- if there's just one thing we could do --

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (grabs hold of Johnny's arms) Now, Mason -- get hold of yourself!... I know how you feel, but get hold of yourself! Suppose the planes are grounded -- Why can't you put it on one of the fast trains?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: But we can't. I told you hours count -- every minute counts. It'd be too late. We need a plane from Salt Lake and we've got one but the pilot wants five thousand dollars to fly it to New York -- (his voice breaks) And Judge, I didn't have anyone else to turn to -- Doolittle interrupts him with a loud shout.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (looks off scene) SIMON! Well, what're you standing there for? The butler comes into the scene.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: My check book!... Get me my check book! CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS as Simon scurries to secretary.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: And get me a pen! Quick! One that will write! And find out where the nearest telegraph office is! Simon scurries out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (he goes to Johnny whose head is buried in his hands -- patting Johnny on the shoulder) You should have gotten in touch with me sooner -- but don't you worry about that serum; we'll have it here and in plenty of time too! As Johnny looks up at Judge Doolittle pitifully and gratefully, with Doolittle's hand still on his shoulder, hold a minute, then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sock flops crazily in the wind. CAMERA MOVES PAST IT DOWN, revealing a stretch of snowy ground with building o airport office below. The circular beacon of the landing field is dimly visible through the storm. AS CAMERA MOVES DOWN we come over the airport office structure which has large lettering covering the roof area. The lettering is partially obliterated by wind-swept snow, but as CAMERA M CLOSER we can make it out: SALT LAKE CITY.

dialogues.speaker: HATTON
dialogues.text: Yeah, Mr. Mason -- the serum's here and the money's here too -- and I could certainly use the dough. But the weather's gotten so bad it's impossible to take off -- (listens a minute) What can I do? -- CAMERA MOVES BACK to take in Collins, Conway and a couple others standing by, listening. Hatton turns an eloquent l of despair on them as he listens.

dialogues.speaker: HATTON
dialogues.text: I know how you feel -- I'm married myself and I've got a couple of kids -- but I got to think of them too. My wife won't let me -- she says if I go she won't be here when I get back -- if I get back. (he puts his hand over the receiver and remarks to the group around him; plaintively) What do you do with a guy like that?

dialogues.speaker: CONWAY
dialogues.text: Let me talk to him. (he takes the phone from Hatton's hands and speaks into it;  belligerently) Now listen you -- what do you think this is -- a suicide club? You can't expect anybody in his right mind to fly a plane on a night like this -- especially an old crate with whiskers. Why don't you -- (he listens a moment and we see his truculence gradually melting) Sure... That's tough... we'd certainly like to help you -- ain't there no other place you could get some of the stuff? Maybe in a few hours, when the weather clears up -- (he listens a moment -- his expression changes. He puts his hand over the receiver and turns to the group around him) (in an awed voice) Gee, the guy's crying -- (picks up receiver) Now wait a minute, buddy... take it easy... Suppose we -- maybe I -- hold the wire! (he puts his hand over receiver and turns to the group behind him; helplessly He just won't take No for an answer. (hesitates, then speaks to Hatton) Jim, could I borrow your plane?

dialogues.speaker: HATTON
dialogues.text: Are you nuts?

dialogues.speaker: CONWAY
dialogues.text: You know how it is -- you've got kids of your own. Suppose you was in his place --

dialogues.speaker: HATTON
dialogues.text: I can't let you have my plane. I've got no insurance on it -- I couldn't get any --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in phone) Hold it a minute -- keep your shirt on -- (to Hatton) I'll give you half the money if you'll loan me the crate.

dialogues.speaker: HATTON
dialogues.text: Suppose you crack it up --

dialogues.speaker: CONWAY
dialogues.text: Then you can keep the whole five -- I won't need it.

dialogues.speaker: HATTON
dialogues.text: I think you're crazy. But, all right -- if you want to.

dialogues.speaker: CONWAY
dialogues.text: (speaking into phone) Okay, buddy -- relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing at the frost covered window, Hatton, Collins and couple of others.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: Do you think he'll ever get off the ground with all that gas?

dialogues.speaker: HATTON
dialogues.text: Well, I did -- going to Honolulu -- Hatton rubs off some of the frost to clear a space on the pane and they peer through at the field. Through the bliz with the beacon lights circling the field, we dimly make Conway's plane. It taxies across the field and takes off the storm. The men listen to the dying sound of the plane's motors. Hatton shrugs and turns to Collins.

dialogues.speaker: HATTON
dialogues.text: I can't say I like that kind of money --  but it looks like I'll be in five grand before morning.

dialogues.speaker: BABY'S ROOM
dialogues.text: The corridor is quite dark, except for such light as may come in from laboratory or perhaps one open door somewher in corridor. Doctor Healy comes out of the baby's room, s Jane coming toward him as he closes the door. He glances down hall and sees in the b.g. the dim figure of a man wheeling something toward the baby's room. He turns quick to Jane, maneuvering so she cannot see what is coming dow the corridor. Jane looks imploringly at the doctor's face.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HEALY
dialogues.text: He's all right -- he's holding his own nicely.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: May I go in and see him?

dialogues.speaker: DR. HEALY
dialogues.text: I don't think you'd better -- not just now.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (getting panicky) Why, doctor? Why don't you want me to see him?

dialogues.speaker: DR. HEALY
dialogues.text: Now, don't worry -- it's just that --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (with tinge of hysteria) Then why don't you want me to see him? She starts to brush past the doctor forcibly, when she st seeing that the man with the wheelbarrow who has come up behind the doctor has opened the door of the baby's room. he does, a light from the baby's room reveals the cylinde of oxygen which he has been wheeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light from the room falling on the cylinder in such a manner as to bring out vividly the word "OXYGEN" printed it.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR HEALY AND JANE
dialogues.text: The shock of seeing the oxygen is the trigger that unloos the pent-up emotion in Jane.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
